questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to a recent episode of seizures. For the past 2 days, she has been sick with fever and headaches. The patient had never had a seizure before, and medical history is unremarkable. Family history is negative for neurological disorders. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is postictal but responsive. She is unable to speak. MRI is obtained, and the results are shown below:  

 

Reproduced form: Wikipedia    
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid analysis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, headaches, and new onset of a seizure. The MRI shows hyperintensities in the temporal lobes, including the hippocampus, which is highly suggestive of herpes simplex virus  (HSV) encephalitis. Due to the significant morbidity and mortality associated with the condition, empiric intravenous acyclovir therapy should be started immediately when HSV encephalitis is suspected.

HSV encephalitis is the most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis. Most cases are caused by type HSV-1, but type 2 is also seen. Patients often present with rapid onset of fever and at least one of the following: altered mentation, focal cranial nerve deficits, hemiparesis, dysphasia, aphasia, ataxia, focal seizures, headache, focal neurologic signs. IV acyclovir should be administered empirically in any patient that is suspected of HSV encephalitis, due to the high mortality and morbidity rates. High level of suspicion includes patients with CSF pleocytosis and encephalitis, focal findings on examination, imaging, or electroencephalography. CSF analysis typically shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis, increased number of erythrocytes (due to hemorrhage), and elevated protein. However, the CSF profile can be normal early in the course of the disease and therefore is not diagnostic. CSF polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is used to identify HSV-1, HSV-2, and enteroviruses. Identification of HSV-1 in the CSF is an efficient, rapid, sensitive, and specific diagnostic test for HSV-1 encephalitis and, therefore, is the test of choice.   

Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, culture, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are required for further evaluation of this patient. The procedure should not be performed until after imaging in any patient with signs of intracranial hypertension, seizure, or focal neurologic deficit to avoid the risk for brain herniation. However, it is important to note that this patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other diagnostic steps.
❌ Empiric antibiotics:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics should be initiated after CSF is obtained or when lumbar puncture is delayed in any patient suspected of having bacterial meningitis; however, this patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other steps.
✅ Intravenous acyclovir :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supportive treatment only:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics may be initiated until a viral cause is confirmed. Supportive care is usually sufficient for confirmed viral cases but certain cases require specific care. This patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other steps.
❌ Surgical drainage:
Incorrect: Antibiotics and surgical drainage are indicated for the treatment of brain abscesses, which typically present with headache, fever, and focal neurologic deficits. This patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other steps.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for right arm numbness and slurred speech. Since awakening 6 hours ago, he has not been able to feel his right upper arm when he touches it. He also noticed that he has been slurring his speech and drooling, with there is liquid leaking out of the right side of his mouth when he drinks. The patient has been using intravenous drugs on and off for the last ten years. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows flattening of the right nasolabial fold and an asymmetric smile. He raises both eyebrows equally well and has a normal eye exam bilaterally. There is subjective sensory loss throughout the right upper extremity and pronator drift of the right arm. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following should be performed next to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast
Cerebrospinal fluid gram stain and culture
Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without iodinated contrast

questions.solution:
This patient has central facial palsy, as evidenced by forehead sparing, along with the presence of other features of intracranial pathology including upper extremity numbness and weakness. The diagnostic workup for an adult with central facial palsy begins with neuroimaging to help differentiate between the most common causes, including stroke, demyelination, tumors, and brain abscesses. This patient’s history of intravenous drug use and presence of fever warrant investigation for intracranial infection, which is best achieved with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without gadolinium contrast.         

Radiographically, brain abscesses will appear as smooth peripheral rim-enhancing masses with central cystic changes. Other causes of central facial palsy can be differentiated by certain radiographic characteristics on MRI including restricted diffusion (acute ischemia), white matter hyperintensities (multiple sclerosis), or multiple contrast-enhancing lesions (metastatic tumors).   

Option Analysis

✅ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Aerobic blood culture:
Incorrect: Aerobic blood culture would help identify a causative organism in a patient with bacteremia caused by a brain abscess but is only positive in 10% of brain abscess cases. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain, with and without contrast, is the preferred diagnostic method. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid gram stain and culture:
Incorrect: Cerebrospinal fluid gram stain and culture would help identify an organism in a patient with bacterial meningitis but may be negative in cases of localized intracranial infection like brain abscess. This patient’s pattern of facial paralysis and arm weakness indicate a focal structural process, and MRI should be performed next. 
❌ Electromyogram and nerve conduction study :
Incorrect: Electromyography and nerve conduction analyses are helpful in the assessment of muscle and nerve function and can help differentiate between peripheral and central etiologies of weakness. In an adult with acute-onset central facial palsy, and signs of central nervous system dysfunction like limb weakness and lack of sensation, neuroimaging with MRI should be performed to determine the etiology. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without iodinated contrast:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in an adult with central facial palsy. CT imaging, though rapidly available, has a lower diagnostic yield than magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), especially when performed without contrast, and should be reserved for patients who are unable to undergo MRI.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents to the emergency department with generalized weakness for the past two days and a tremor in both arms. The patient reports a headache over this period, sensitivity to light, and muscle aches. On review of systems, there is a history of recent insect bites while camping. Past medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears lethargic but answers questions appropriately. There is diffuse 4+/5 weakness in all extremities. A maculopapular rash is noted over the trunk, back, and bilateral upper extremities. A diagnostic lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following would likely be positive on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of encephalitis, including lethargy, headache, photophobia, fever, rash, symmetric limb weakness, and tremor. The most likely diagnosis is West Nile viral encephalitis, given the recent insect bites (potentially mosquitoes) while camping. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the presence of West Nile virus IgM antibodies in the CSF. Individuals who are immunocompromised, older adults, and those with diabetes are at increased risk for this infection.       

Encephalitis may result from infectious or autoimmune causes. Laboratory evaluation typically includes a complete blood count (CBC) with differential, serum antibody testing, CSF analysis, and neuroimaging to help narrow the differential. Neuroimaging findings are often nonspecific and may show edema, hemorrhage, ischemia, hyperintensities, calcifications, or ring-enhancing lesions. In infectious encephalitis, CSF testing frequently identifies the causative agent (e.g. positive Toxoplasma gondii PCR), while autoimmune encephalitis is often associated with the presence of specific autoantibodies (e.g. anti-NMDA receptor antibodies).       

Option Analysis

✅ West Nile (WN) virus IgM antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Herpes simplex virus (HSV)-1/2 PCR:
Incorrect: HSV encephalitis typically presents prodromal upper respiratory symptoms, olfactory hallucinations, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. It is not typically associated with a rash or recent insect exposure. 
❌ Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) IgM antibodies:
Incorrect: VZV encephalitis is more commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals or older adults and may present with acute, stroke-like symptoms. While some patients may have a recent history of chickenpox or shingles infection, these rashes are typically vesicular and not usually described as a diffuse maculopapular rash. Additionally, it is not associated with recent insect exposure. 
❌ Toxoplasma gondii PCR :
Incorrect: Toxoplasma gondii encephalitis more commonly occurs in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with advanced HIV/AIDS. Additionally, while it can cause focal neurologic deficits, it is not typically associated with a diffuse rash, tremor, or insect exposure. 
❌ Taenia solium antigen:
Incorrect: Neurocysticercosis, caused by the larval form of Taenia solium, is more commonly associated with travel to endemic regions, such as Latin America, sub-Saharan Africa, or Southeast Asia. It may cause seizures, signs of increased intracranial pressure, eye pain, and vision loss. It is not typically associated with tremor, diffuse rash, or insect exposure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of seizure-like activity. The patient's partner reports progressive confusion, headache, and fever over the past two days. Earlier today, the patient suddenly became rigid with rhythmic jerking movements of the limbs lasting two minutes, followed by combativeness. En route to the hospital, the patient became drowsy and somnolent. Past medical history is noncontributory, and no medications are taken. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 58/min, respirations are 8/min, blood pressure is 152/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on 10 liters via nonrebreather facemask. The patient appears stuporous on examination, without abnormal movements. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. What is the next most appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive confusion, headache, fever, and seizure-like activity, raising concern for encephalitis. The declining level of consciousness, bradycardia, hypertension, and bradypnea suggest elevated intracranial pressure. Additionally, hypoxia despite supplemental oxygen indicates impending respiratory failure. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are indicated to protect the airway and support ventilation.       

Encephalitis, or inflammation of the brain parenchyma, can occur due to infections or autoimmune conditions. Initial management should prioritize stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary to secure the airway and ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation. Intravenous access should be established and continuous vital sign monitoring initiated. Patients who are unstable should be assessed for signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as worsening mental status, focal neurologic deficits, or features of the Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations). Once stabilized, a focused history and physical examination can help guide further investigations and treatment.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous lorazepam:
Incorrect: Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is indicated for ongoing seizure activity. This patient is no longer seizing. The immediate concern is respiratory insufficiency. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture and CSF analysis will likely be necessary to evaluate for a CNS infection, but testing should be delayed until the airway is protected, and the patient is stabilized.  
❌ Intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics will likely be indicated for suspected encephalitis, but treatment should follow initial stabilization, including airway and breathing management. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast:
Incorrect: A non-contrast head CT would be preferred in the acute setting to evaluate for contraindications to lumbar puncture. However, imaging should be delayed until the airway and breathing are stabilized.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of severe headache. For the past two days, the patient has experienced constant, intensifying headaches with light sensitivity and neck stiffness. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and sickle cell disease. Medications include daily metformin and occasional use of oxycodone for pain management. The patient consumes 3-4 drinks per week. On review of systems, an ear infection was treated last month with oral antibiotics. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is sensitive to light and resists passive movement of the neck. There is a petechial and purpuric rash on the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following aspects of the history placed the patient most at risk for the development of the current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of bacterial meningitis, including headache, neck stiffness, and fever. His history of sickle cell disease renders him functionally asplenic, which increases the risk of infection with encapsulated microorganisms like Neisseria meningitidis. Meningitis associated with this pathogen typically presents with a petechial or purpuric rash, often non-blanching, and primarily distributed on the trunk and extremities.

Patients with meningitis may also experience nausea, vomiting, confusion, or even seizures. Additional risk factors include recent neurosurgical procedures, head trauma, infection, immunocompromised state, or incomplete vaccination. These factors can influence the likelihood of certain causative organisms and guide the selection of initial antimicrobial therapy.

Examination may reveal signs of meningeal irritation, including a positive Brudzinski or Kernig sign. Altered mental status and focal neurological deficits may also be present. Particular attention should be given to signs of increased intracranial pressure, including Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respirations), a dilated pupil, or papilledema.

Option Analysis

✅ Sickle cell disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alcohol use:
Incorrect: Alcohol use may increase the risk of bacterial meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes. However, the presence of sickle cell disease renders this patient functionally asplenic, placing him at higher risk of infection with Neisseria meningitidis, which is associated with the described rash.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus may increase the risk of bacterial meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes. However, the presence of sickle cell disease renders this patient functionally asplenic, placing him at higher risk of infection with Neisseria meningitidis, which is associated with the described rash.
❌ Recent acute otitis media:
Incorrect: Preceding head and neck infections, like otitis media, may increase the risk of bacterial meningitis or brain abscess caused by Streptococcus species. However, the presence of sickle cell disease renders this patient functionally asplenic, placing him at higher risk of infection with Neisseria meningitidis, which is associated with the described rash.
❌ Opioid use:
Incorrect: Opioid withdrawal can cause symptoms like headache and sweating, but this patient’s fever, petechial/purpuric rash, and other signs of meningeal irritation are concerning for bacterial meningitis. This patient’s sickle cell disease increases the risk of Neisseria meningitidis infection.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of headache. For the past two weeks, the patient has experienced a gradually intensifying, constant headache with associated light sensitivity and neck stiffness. The patient has a medical history significant for HIV, and he has been non-adherent with antiretroviral agents. On review of systems, the patient has had intermittent fever and cough. The patient does not currently take any medications. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is squinting and resisting passive movement of the neck. With forward flexion of the neck, the hips flex bilaterally. A lumbar puncture is performed; results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this patient’s condition?

 Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis Result 
 Appearance Clear
 Glucose 60 mg/dL
 Protein 70 mg/dL
 White blood cell count 450/microL
 Red blood cell count 0/microL
 Opening pressure 30 cmH2O
 India ink stain Positive
 Acid-fast stain Negative
questions.solution:
This immunocompromised patient presents with signs and symptoms of cryptococcal meningitis, including fever, headache, neck stiffness, and light sensitivity. The subacute presentation is typical of cryptococcal meningitis, which is most common in patients with a CD4 count <100 cells/microL. The CSF white blood cell (WBC) count is often elevated but typically not exceeding 500 cells/microL. Glucose levels are usually slightly low or normal, protein levels may be normal or elevated, and opening pressure is often high. A positive India ink stain is key in distinguishing this from other forms of meningitis.

In tuberculous meningitis, CSF analysis may show a similar WBC count and glucose and protein levels, but the India ink stain will be negative, and an acid-fast stain will be positive. Non-tuberculous bacterial meningitis typically features a very high WBC count with a neutrophilic predominance, low glucose, and elevated protein. Viral meningitis shows a variable WBC count with a lymphocytic predominance, normal or slightly low glucose, and normal or slightly elevated protein. In herpes simplex virus (HSV) meningitis, the red blood cell count may be significantly elevated even with a non-traumatic lumbar puncture.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Cryptococcus neoformans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Bacterial meningitis typically features a very high CSF white blood cell count (>1,000/microL), low glucose, and high protein (>100 mg/dL). In contrast, this case features a lower WBC count (450/microL), normal glucose, and only mildly elevated protein (70 mg/dL), along with positive India ink staining; this profile is more suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis.
❌ Listeria monocytogenes:
Incorrect: Bacterial meningitis typically features a very high CSF white blood cell count (>1,000/microL), low glucose, and high protein (>100 mg/dL). In contrast, this case features a lower WBC count (450/microL), normal glucose, and only mildly elevated protein (70 mg/dL), along with positive India ink staining; this profile is more suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis.
❌ Herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Viral meningitis typically features a slightly higher CSF white blood cell count (up to 1,000/microL) and the characteristic presence of red blood cells (RBCs). In contrast, the lower WBC count (450/microL), positive India ink staining, and lack of RBCs in this patient’s CSF profile are more suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis.
❌ Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Tuberculous meningitis typically features low glucose in the CSF, in addition to a positive acid-fast test. In contrast, the normal glucose and positive India ink staining in this case are more suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner because of confusion. The partner reports that the patient has had fever and headache for the past 2 days for which he has been taking acetaminophen without improvement. While in the emergency room, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs. His temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 159/99 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is confused and disoriented. Neurological examination is negative for Kernig sign and Brudzinski sign. Babinski sign is positive bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. MRI brain shows hyperintense areas in the left temporal lobe. Lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis results are shown below. Inhibition of which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that is used to treat this patient’s condition?

 Laboratory features
 CSF analysis  Result 
 Opening pressure  Normal 
 Protein  87 mg/dL 
 Glucose  65 mg/dL 
 Erythrocyte  30/mm3 
 Leukocytes  90/mm3 
 Lymphocytes  92%
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis (confusion, seizure, and headache). The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings of hemorrhagic lymphocytic pleocytosis, an elevated protein count, and normal glucose, in combination with inflammation of bilateral temporal lobes, further supports the diagnosis. The patient should be treated promptly with acyclovir, a guanosine analog.   

The guanosine analogs also include valacyclovir, penciclovir, famciclovir, ganciclovir, and valganciclovir. Once inside an infected cell, these drugs get phosphorylated by viral kinase to the active triphosphate form, which acts as a guanosine analog. When this analog is inserted into the replicating viral DNA, it causes the growing DNA chain to terminate by competing with deoxyguanosine triphosphate for viral DNA polymerase and being incorporated into viral DNA. Resistance can develop due to mutated viral kinase.   

Adverse effects include headache, nausea, bone marrow suppression, and nephrotoxicity.  



Option Analysis

❌ DNA-dependent RNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Rifamycins (e.g. rifampin) act by inhibiting the bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It is effective for the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and prophylaxis against meningococcal infection. It is not effective against herpes simplex virus 1 infection.
✅ Viral DNA polymerase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial cell wall synthesis:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone, a bacterial cell wall synthesis inhibitor, is usually used in the management of bacterial meningitis but is not effective against herpes simplex virus 1 encephalitis.
❌ Viral protease:
Incorrect: Viral protease inhibitors (e.g. indinavir) prevents maturation of new viruses and are important in the treatment of HIV and hepatitis C virus infections. It is not effective against herpes simplex virus 1 encephalitis.
❌ Ergosterol synthesis:
Incorrect: Antifungal agents such as azoles (e.g. fluconazole) inhibit ergosterol synthesis by inhibiting the cytochrome P-450 enzyme that converts lanosterol to ergosterol. It is effective against local fungal infections such as candidiasis. This patient most likely has herpes simplex virus 1 encephalitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of headache. For the past week, the patient’s head pain has been gradually intensifying and worsens with coughing or straining during a bowel movement. Nausea is present, along with several episodes of nonbilious emesis today. Blurry vision is noted bilaterally. Past medical history is noncontributory aside from a recent episode of a right otitis media for which oral amoxicillin was prescribed. However, the course was not completed due to nausea. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 8-10/min and are irregular, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilateral papilledema and drift in the left upper extremity. Reflexes are normal in both upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Flattening the head of the bed

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of a brain abscess, including headache, fever, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), including headaches worsened by Valsalva maneuvers, nausea, vomiting, blurry vision, bilateral papilledema, and the Cushing triad (bradycardia, irregular respirations, hypertension). After stabilizing the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is to manage ICP through elevating the head of the bed, hyperventilation, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.  

Once the patient is stable, a focused history may reveal risk factors for the development of a brain abscess, such as a recent dental or neurosurgical procedure, head trauma, head or neck infection, systemic infection, or an immunocompromised state.

The diagnosis can be made through neuroimaging, often revealing a ring-enhancing mass lesion with a central area of necrosis or pus. Blood cultures may help identify the causative organism, but lumbar puncture is usually of low diagnostic yield and is contraindicated in patients with elevated ICP due to the risk of precipitating herniation.

Empiric antimicrobial therapy for aerobic and anaerobic bacterial pathogens should be initiated as soon as possible, along with corticosteroids for cerebral edema, and anti-seizure medication may be considered.

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperosmolar therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Flattening the head of the bed:
Incorrect: This patient displays signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, which should be managed by elevating the head of the bed, rather than flattening it. Additional helpful measures would include hyperventilation, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.
❌ Intubation with hypoventilation:
Incorrect: This patient displays signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, which should be managed with hyperventilation, rather than hypoventilation. Additional helpful measures would include elevating the head of the bed, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms suggestive of a brain abscess, including evidence of increased intracranial pressure. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the setting of increased intracranial pressure due to the risk of brain herniation.
❌ Electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: This patient has signs and symptoms of a brain abscess with increased intracranial pressure. Immediate management of intracranial pressure takes precedence. Empiric anti-seizure medication may be administered without delaying care to obtain an electroencephalogram.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical personnel for evaluation of confusion. A passerby found the patient speaking incoherently in a park and noted a right facial droop. Past medical history and medication use history are unknown. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented and dysarthric. There is a right facial droop and right-sided arm drift. The patient is holding her head. Laboratory studies are shown below. A computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast reveals a ring-enhancing mass lesion with a central area of hypodensity in the left frontal cortex. The patient is started on intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole. Which of the following is the next step in management?    

 Laboratory test     Result 
 Serum leukocyte count 30,000/mm3
 Blood glucose 100 mg/dL
 Urine drug screen Negative
 Serum ethanol level <0.02%
 Anaerobic blood culture No growth to date
 Aerobic blood culture No growth to date

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of a brain abscess, including headache, fever, and focal neurological deficits. After obtaining blood cultures and confirming the diagnosis with neuroimaging findings, empiric intravenous antibiotics should be administered based on the patient’s history. Needle aspiration or surgical drainage of the abscess should follow, allowing for samples to be sent for culture and PCR testing to tailor antimicrobial therapy.

Most brain abscesses are bacterial, so a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefepime) should be initiated to cover streptococcal species, along with metronidazole for anaerobic coverage. In immunocompromised patients, additional antibacterial agents may be needed. For patients with a history of direct penetrating trauma or a recent neurosurgical procedure, vancomycin should be added for coverage of Staphylococcus aureus.

Corticosteroids should be initiated for signs of increased intracranial pressure or evidence of cerebral edema on neuroimaging. Empiric, broad spectrum anti-seizure medication may be added if the patient is confused or convulsing.

A lumbar puncture is usually not indicated in the case of a brain abscess and is typically of low yield. If intracranial pressure is elevated, performing this procedure could precipitate brain herniation.

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: A lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the case of a brain abscess, as it is typically low yield and could precipitate brain herniation in the presence of increased intracranial pressure.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Incorrect: This patient’s CT confirms the diagnosis of a brain abscess. An MRI would not change the immediate management plan, which focuses on drainage and culture of the abscess.
❌ Intravenous cefazolin:
Incorrect: This patient has a brain abscess, for which a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone or cefotaxime) is already the preferred choice. Cefazolin, a first-generation cephalosporin, does not provide adequate coverage.
❌ Electroencephalogram (EEG):
Incorrect: This patient has a brain abscess, for which the next step in management includes collection of a sample for culture and PCR testing. Empiric anti-seizure medication may be administered without delaying care to obtain an EEG.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after his roommate found him pale and diaphoretic in his room. The patient states that he uses intravenous (IV) drugs regularly. Three days ago, he began having a low-grade fever, and over the ensuing days, he began having low back pain. Today he felt too weak to get out of bed. He has no significant past medical or surgical history. Temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), heart rate is 124/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, blood pressure is 88/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears ill. Physical exam reveals dry mucous membranes. There is focal tenderness to palpation at L5 and S1 with loss of sensation in the saddle area. Labs are drawn, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, and blood cultures. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient with recent IV drug use who presents with fever, acute low back pain, and focal pain over the spine with saddle anesthesia, likely has a spinal epidural abscess (SEA). His hypotension is concerning for sepsis caused by the abscess. While the imaging modality of choice for a SEA is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine with and without contrast, unstable patients require resuscitation with intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics before proceeding to imaging and treatment.

Epidural abscess is a rare suppurative infection of the central nervous system. SEA can be caused by direct inoculation during a spinal procedure, contiguous spread from a local infection, or a secondary complication of any condition that results in bacteremia. The leading causative agent is Staphylococcus aureus. Risk factors for SEA include intravenous drug use, diabetes, chronic indwelling venous catheters, concurrent infection, recent spinal procedures, and immunosuppression.

The initial manifestations of SEA are often nonspecific and include fever and malaise. The classical diagnostic triad consists of fever, back pain, and neurologic deficits; however, only a small proportion of patients have all three components at presentation. The treatment of choice in SEA is surgical drainage and tailored antibiotic therapy when possible, however, medical management alone is appropriate for some patients based on acuity and other risk factors. In an unstable patient with a suspected diagnosis of SEA, the goal is to stabilize the patient with immediate IV fluids and to give antibiotics after the collection of blood cultures.   

Option Analysis

❌ Spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without contrast:
Incorrect: In patients with a presumed spinal epidural abscess, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with gadolinium contrast is the diagnostic modality of choice. However, this patient is unstable and requires resuscitation before moving forward with imaging.
❌ Surgery consultation:
Incorrect: A surgery consultation for eventual operative decompression and drainage is the definitive management in most patients with spinal epidural abscess. However, this patient needs to be stabilized before any further management.
✅ Intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Image-guided biopsy and culture:
Incorrect: Image-guided biopsy and culture may be appropriate for patients with spinal epidural abscesses and mild symptoms, without neurologic deficits, or for those who are unable to tolerate surgery or are unlikely to benefit from it due to severity. This patient has a focal neurologic deficit and signs of systemic infection. Initial resuscitation and imaging are necessary before a final management decision can be made.
❌ Thoracic and Lumbar X-rays:
Incorrect: Plain radiographs of the spine may reveal changes of osteomyelitis or discitis, but are rarely diagnostic for spinal epidural abscesses, making magnetic resonance imaging a better choice when suspicion of spinal infection is high. However, this patient requires stabilization before any diagnostic imaging can be considered.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with back pain and fever. About four days ago, the patient began feeling tenderness in his mid-back. He had been moving heavy boxes and thought he strained a muscle. He developed a fever this morning, which prompted him to come to the emergency department. Past medical history is notable for degenerative spine disease and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.4oC (101.2°F) pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Exam is notable for midline thoracic tenderness on palpation. Neurological exam is nonfocal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine shows decreased signal intensity in the vertebral bodies of T2 and T3 and loss of endplate definition on T1-weighted images. Initial blood cultures come back positive for gram-positive cocci in both bottles. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Heat packs and rest for 2-4 weeks

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with acute back pain and fever in the setting of diabetes and degenerative spine disease. MRI findings are consistent with vertebral osteomyelitis in T2 and T3. Given positive blood cultures of an organism that is most likely Staphylococcus Aureus (S. Aureus), this patient should begin empiric treatment of vertebral osteomyelitis with intravenous antibiotics.

In a patient with MRI findings consistent with vertebral osteomyelitis and blood cultures consistent with a common pathogen for osteomyelitis, such as S. Aureus, a presumptive diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis can be made. The clinician should next determine whether there are signs or findings of focal neurological deficit, epidural abscess, or cord compression. If there are not, and the patient does not have signs of sepsis, then they can be treated empirically with intravenous antibiotics. Patients with clinical findings and imaging findings concerning vertebral osteomyelitis but with negative blood cultures should have an image-guided culture and biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

If, however, the patient has signs of focal neurological deficit, cord compression, or MRI findings of epidural abscess, proceeding directly to surgery is the most appropriate next step in management.

Option Analysis

❌ Operative decompression and drainage:
Incorrect: In patients with cord compression, focal neurological deficits, or findings of an epidural abscess, the next step should be operative decompression and drainage. However, this patient does not have any of these signs or MRI findings, therefore, initial management with antibiotics is reasonable.
❌ Computed tomography-guided biopsy and culture:
Incorrect: This answer choice is appropriate if vertebral osteomyelitis is suspected and blood cultures are negative, or in patients with sepsis who are stable enough to proceed with image-guided biopsy. In this case, with positive blood cultures with a likely infecting organism for vertebral osteomyelitis and corresponding advanced imaging findings, the diagnosis can be presumed, and antibiotic treatment should be started.
✅ Empiric intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Discharge with oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: Patients with a presumptive diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis should have intravenous antibiotics, given their shorter onset of action and better bioavailability. Once the patient shows improvement in symptoms patients can be transitioned to oral antibiotics in preparation for discharge.
❌ Heat packs and rest for 2-4 weeks:
Incorrect: Patients with a paraspinal muscle strain should alternate between heat and ice to the affected area and should rest as needed. This patient most likely has vertebral osteomyelitis and conservative care would not be sufficient management; intravenous antibiotics are indicated.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from an assisted living facility with shooting pain down his legs. His caregiver states that for the past three weeks, he has had pain at rest and with movement which the patient describes as a jolt of pain down his legs. The patient has also felt feverish in the last three weeks but has not had chills or weight loss. He has a history of Parkinson disease and has a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) for total parenteral nutrition (TPN). He has a remote history of intravenous (IV) drug use 20 years ago, but none since. His HbA1c is 5.4%, last checked two months ago. Temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient has a PICC line in place with surrounding erythema, without drainage or fluctuance. Midline lumbar tenderness to palpation and 4/5 weakness in the lower extremities bilaterally. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging shows a fluid collection in the lumbar epidural space with rim enhancement and a hypointense center. Which of the following most likely led to this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Prior History of IV drug use

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of neuropathic leg pain and low-grade fevers. The exam findings of fever, focal lumbar tenderness, and bilateral lower extremity weakness suggest spinal epidural abscess (SEA), as confirmed by MRI. The presence of a PICC greatly predisposes this patient to SEA.

Spinal epidural abscess can develop in days or months and be a secondary complication of any condition that results in bacteremia. For example, injection drug use, dental abscess or manipulation, infective endocarditis, and indwelling catheters are all risk factors for SEA. Spinal trauma and medical interventions can directly cause SEA, including epidural catheter placement, lumbar puncture, and spinal surgeries. Spinal epidural abscess can also be caused by contiguous spread from a local infection, such as osteomyelitis of the vertebrae or abscess in a muscle.

The classic triad of clinical findings in a patient with SEA includes fever, back pain, and neurologic deficit; however, this triad is only initially present in a small number of patients. A high index of suspicion is needed to diagnose SEA, and cases often progress significantly before detection. Physical exam findings may reveal spinal tenderness and neurological deficits such as sensory loss, motor weakness, radiculopathy, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and even paralysis.

Option Analysis

❌ Prior History of IV drug use:
Incorrect: While current IV drug use significantly increases the risk of spinal epidural abscesses, a remote history of IV drug use does not.
❌ Parkinson Disease:
Incorrect: Parkinson disease is a risk factor for a multitude of psychiatric, motor, and autonomic conditions, but it is not a risk factor for a spinal epidural abscess.
✅ PICC line:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes is a risk factor for a spinal epidural abscess, however, this patient’s recent HbA1c level indicates he likely does not currently have diabetes since he is not on any diabetes medications.
❌ TPN:
Incorrect: TPN is a risk factor for metabolic dysfunction, including hyperglycemia, cirrhosis, and refeeding syndrome. It is not, in itself, a risk factor for a spinal epidural abscess.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of low back pain and fever. He has had chronic pain in the lower back for many years and received a lumbar facet joint injection with his pain specialist three months ago. Six weeks ago, he began noticing persistent pain in the lower back, different from his usual symptoms and unrelieved by medication or rest. The day before admission he developed a fever. The patient has a history of diabetes treated with Metformin and rheumatoid arthritis treated with daily prednisone. Temperature is 38.6oF (101.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 134/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Exam is notable for midline tenderness over L1. Neurological exam is nonfocal. X-ray reveals destructive changes in the body of L1 and L2 with the collapse of the disc space between the vertebrae. Which of the following next steps would be best to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with six weeks of lower back pain and new onset fever. The tenderness to palpation noted at L1, along with the destructive changes seen in the body of L1 and L2 on imaging make vertebral osteomyelitis the most likely diagnosis. Image-guided biopsy and culture are the preferred methods of confirming this diagnosis and will help guide antibiotic therapy. This patient’s recent facet injection may have led to his infection, especially with the additional risk factors of diabetes and immunosuppression from chronic steroid use.

Vertebral osteomyelitis should be suspected in the setting of new or worsening back or neck pain, especially with fever, and/or the presence of bloodstream infection or infective endocarditis. It should also be suspected in patients with fever and new peripheral neurologic symptoms (with or without back pain), and in patients with new back or neck pain following a recent episode of bacteremia (especially with S. aureus) or fungemia. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast should be ordered when vertebral osteomyelitis is suspected MRI. Results that are consistent with vertebral osteomyelitis include vertebral body bone marrow signal abnormality, loss of intervertebral disc space height, loss of margins between the vertebral body and disc space, vertebral body end plate destruction, and surrounding bone marrow and soft tissue edema. MRI in patients with a spinal epidural abscess would show fluid collection with rim enhancement and a hypointense center, dural enhancement, paraspinal and bone marrow edema, with longitudinal extension along the spinal column.

The diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis is established based on positive cultures obtained from an image-guided biopsy of the involved vertebra(e) and/or disc space. The diagnosis may be inferred in the setting of clinical and radiographic findings typical of vertebral osteomyelitis and positive blood cultures with a likely pathogen such as S. aureus. Similarly, the diagnosis may be inferred in the setting of histopathologic findings consistent with infection in the absence of positive culture data, particularly in the setting of recent antibiotic administration.

Option Analysis

❌ Magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most sensitive radiographic technique for detecting vertebral osteomyelitis; however, it cannot confirm the diagnosis. Confirmation requires biopsy and culture.
❌ Computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: Computed tomography (CT) is a reasonable alternative imaging modality when magnetic resonance imaging is not available and vertebral osteomyelitis is suspected; however, it cannot confirm the diagnosis. Confirmation requires biopsy and culture.
✅ Image-guided biopsy and culture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: If a patient is unable to undergo an image-guided biopsy and culture, the diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis may be inferred in the setting of clinical and radiographic findings typical of vertebral osteomyelitis and positive blood cultures with a likely pathogen such as Staphylococcus aureus.
❌ Operative exploration:
Incorrect: Taking a patient to the operating room for the diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis is an unnecessary risk in this patient and not the preferred modality for confirming the diagnosis. Image-guided biopsy and culture are preferred for confirming the diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of severe headaches, which are worse in the morning and have been ongoing for the past month. They are 8/10 in severity and throbbing in quality. She has also experienced associated nausea and vomiting. Moreover, her ability to concentrate has declined, and she has experienced word-finding difficulty. Vital signs are within normal limits. Strength and sensation are intact in the upper and lower extremities. An MRI scan of the brain is obtained, which reveals a multicentric, hemorrhagic tumor in the right temporal lobe. She is prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to decrease cerebral edema associated with the mass. Which of the following glucocorticoids has the most prolonged duration of action?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids can be classified according to their duration of action. Of the answer choices listed, dexamethasone has the longest course of action. It can be administered orally, intravenously, or via inhalation. It is often used to treat inflammation, acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis, cerebral edema (as in this clinical vignette), shock, allergic conditions, and multiple myeloma. It is very potent and can cause marked suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. For this reason, it is also used in the dexamethasone suppression test, which assists in diagnosing Cushing syndrome.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hydrocortisone:
Incorrect: Hydrocortisone is a short-acting glucocorticoid that can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. It has the lowest potency among glucocorticoids. It can systemically treat acute adrenal insufficiency and topically treat skin rashes.
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Prednisone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
❌ Prednisolone:
Incorrect: Prednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders. Moreover, since prednisolone is the biologically active form of prednisone, it is often used in patients with liver disease who cannot convert prednisone to prednisolone.
❌ Methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Methylprednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
✅ Dexamethasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency room with incoherent speech. He is accompanied by his spouse, who states the patient has had a headache for two weeks and that he appeared confused this morning. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and diabetes. His current medications include warfarin, lisinopril, and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. He returned from a trip to India a month ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are within normal limits. His speech is intangible, but he can pick up a pen and copy a picture of a matchstick when prompted. Axial MRI scan reveals a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum. Following a biopsy, he is initiated on procarbazine, lomustine, and vincristine regimen. Which of the following adverse effects can be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination
Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction
Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor

questions.solution:
This patient presents with expressive motor aphasia, chronic headache, and an MRI revealing a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.  

Procarbazine is a non-cell, cycle-specific alkylating agent indicated in treating Hodgkin lymphoma, glioblastoma multiforme, and other brain tumors. Its mechanism of action is not well defined. Myelosuppression is the most common, acute, dose-limiting toxicity of this agent. Resultant effects include depression of all cell lineages resulting in pallor secondary to anemia, bacterial infections due to leukopenia, and bleeding from mucous membranes due to thrombocytopenia. Granulocyte stimulating factors such as filgrastim are commonly administered in case of bone marrow suppression. Other adverse effects of procarbazine include pulmonary toxicity and secondary leukemia. Procarbazine has also been shown to induce mild reversible encephalopathy and neuropathy. 

Option Analysis

❌ Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination:
Incorrect: These symptoms indicate a presentation suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Cardiotoxicity is anticipated with the administration of doxorubicin and daunorubicin.
❌ Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction:
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody instrumental in treating HER2-positive breast cancers. Reversible cardiotoxicity is a known complication of its use and manifests as a reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction. 
❌ Transaminitis :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can cause hepatotoxicity at all doses. Patients may present with transaminitis or fibrosis. Hepatotoxicity is not associated with procarbazine, vincristine, or lomustine use. 
✅ Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infertility :
Incorrect: Alkylating agents like cyclophosphamide are known to exert long-term effects on male and female fertility. Women on cyclophosphamide experience premature menopause and infertility, while men may have a reduction in sperm count. Infertility is not a known adverse effect of procarbazine, lomustine, or vincristine.

questions.text: A 40- year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate for evaluation of  convulsions. His roommate states the patient was experiencing dizziness and was walking “funny” earlier in the day. He does not have a fever, rash, vomiting, or headache. His medical history includes allergic rhinitis, AIDS, and primary CNS lymphoma treated with methotrexate, teniposide, carmustine, prednisone, and rituximab. He last received treatment two days ago. His current medications include HAART and over-the-counter decongestants. He uses intravenous heroin and smokes cocaine occasionally. He consumes two to three beers daily; his last drink was three hours ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals needle tracks in both arms. Mucous membranes are moist. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. He appears tired and lethargic but responds to verbal commands. He moves all his extremities spontaneously, and deep tendon reflexes are symmetric. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication/substance responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Indirect neurotransmitter that increases the concentration of sympathomimetic agents
Inhibition of the reuptake of sympathomimetic biogenic amines
Cross-linking of DNA strands in the central nervous system
Withdrawal from a CNS depressant acting on GABA receptors

questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological symptoms suggest carmustine toxicity in the setting of treatment for primary CNS lymphoma. Carmustine belongs to the class of medications called nitrosoureas that act as alkylating agents. These medications require bioactivation of cytochrome P450 enzymes in the liver, cross the blood-brain barrier and induce DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links.    

Nitrosoureas like carmustine and lomustine are potentially neurotoxic when administered in high doses and include adverse effects such as convulsions, dizziness, and ataxia.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Indirect neurotransmitter that increases the concentration of sympathomimetic agents:
Incorrect:  Amphetamines like methamphetamine act as indirect neurotransmitters by incorporating in cytoplasmic vesicles and increasing concentrations of sympathetic agents like norepinephrine and epinephrine. Methamphetamine intoxication should be considered in patients with psychomotor agitation (including seizures), diaphoresis, hypertension, tachycardia, and dilated pupils. 
❌ Agonist at mu receptors :
Incorrect: Opioids like morphine act on mu receptors distributed throughout the central and peripheral nervous system. Opioid intoxication presents with depressed mental status, respiratory drive, and miotic pupils. Opioid withdrawal can present with a dysphoric mood, diarrhea, increased lacrimation, tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension. 
❌ Inhibition of the reuptake of sympathomimetic biogenic amines :
Incorrect: Cocaine is a stimulant that increases the availability of sympathomimetic biogenic amines like dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine by blocking presynaptic reuptake.  Acute cocaine intoxication can present with psychomotor agitation (seizures, coma), chest pain, and vitals reflecting hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and dilated pupils.   
✅ Cross-linking of DNA strands in the central nervous system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Withdrawal from a CNS depressant acting on GABA receptors:
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal can present with withdrawal seizures typically six to forty-eight hours after drinking has ceased. Other symptoms, such as agitation and tremors, are likely. Physical findings include hypertension, tachycardia, and diaphoresis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a 3-week history of headaches and excessive drooling. These symptoms are associated with an unsteady gait. The headaches occur in the early morning and are often associated with vomiting, resulting in missed school days. Other than the headache, there is no history of pain, abnormal sensations, loss of consciousness, or fever. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the child is alert, cooperative, and oriented to time, place, and person. A wide-based gait is observed. Facial asymmetry is noted with deviation of the mouth to the right side and absence of the left nasolabial fold. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain reveals a diffuse, infiltrative, and minimally enhancing lesion in the pons. Which of the following physical examination findings is expected with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 6-year-old boy presents with features consistent with diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG), including early morning headaches and vomiting, difficulty swallowing (indicated by excessive drooling), facial weakness, and ataxia. Brain MRI confirms the diagnosis by revealing a characteristic mass in the pons. Hyperreflexia and clonus are also expected on examination.       

In children presenting with early morning headaches and vomiting, a brain tumor should be suspected, particularly in the midline or posterior fossa. The presence of ataxia suggests a posterior fossa mass. When hyperreflexia and clonus are observed along with cranial nerve palsies, the findings are more consistent with DIPG.         

DIPG is an aggressive brainstem tumor that typically affects children between 5 and 10 years of age. Common symptoms include visual changes (e.g. double vision), swallowing and speech difficulties, and, in younger children, signs such as early handedness. Physical examination often reveals multiple cranial nerve palsies and crossed findings, such as facial weakness on one side and contralateral hemiparesis. MRI characteristically shows a diffuse, expansile, infiltrative, and minimally enhancing mass in the pons. These tumors are diagnosed radiographically and are not amenable to surgical resection, resulting in a poor prognosis.    

Option Analysis

❌ Torticollis  :
Incorrect: Torticollis can be seen in patients with posterior fossa masses. Although these patients may present with early morning headaches and ataxia, the presence of swallowing difficulty, hemiparesis, facial palsy, and brain MRI showing a mass in the pons is more consistent with diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would typically reveal hyperreflexia and clonus. 
✅ Hyperreflexia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Nystagmus  :
Incorrect: Nystagmus can be seen as part of Parinaud syndrome in patients with a pineal mass, which typically presents with upward gaze palsy and poorly reactive pupils. This patient's findings are more consistent with a diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would normally reveal hyperreflexia and clonus. 
❌ Short stature  :
Incorrect: Short stature, delayed linear growth, and delayed puberty are characteristic of suprasellar tumors due to pressure on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This patient's findings are more consistent with a diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would typically reveal hyperreflexia and clonus. 
❌ Tremors  :
Incorrect: Tremors can be seen in patients with brainstem and pineal masses. This patient's findings are more consistent with a diffuse pontine intrinsic glioma. Physical exam would typically reveal hyperreflexia and clonus.

questions.text: A previously healthy 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by a parent for disorientation. According to the parent, the child woke up in the morning and did not recognize family members. The symptoms are associated with right-sided upper and lower extremity weakness over the past few days, which had been attributed to tiredness after a sports event. There has been no vomiting, headache, seizures, or fever. Family and developmental histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 115/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented to time, place, and person. Neurological exam reveals 3/5 strength with hyporeflexia in the right upper and lower extremities. Strength and tone are normal on the left side. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Blood glucose, electrolytes, and complete blood count are within normal limits. While additional laboratory studies are pending, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and oxygen saturation drops to 80%. There is poor respiratory effort, and oxygenation does not improve with nasal cannula. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
The 9-year-old patient’s presentation with disorientation, hemiparesis, and seizures strongly suggests an underlying brain tumor. Following the acute seizure episode, the patient develops acute respiratory distress, necessitating immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation.         

Hemispheric masses, such as glioblastoma multiforme or primitive neuroectodermal tumors, commonly present with seizures. Additional findings may include focal weakness, sensory changes, and alterations in cognitive function including behavior, personality, and speech. Older children may report headaches, while infants might demonstrate early handedness. Physical examination findings can include altered levels of consciousness, motor weakness or paralysis, asymmetric reflexes, and vision or hearing loss.       

In the setting of a seizure due to a suspected brain tumor, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the immediate priority is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. For patients with respiratory distress, emergent intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required. Intravenous (IV) access should be obtained, and the patient should be placed on continuous vital sign monitoring. IV fluids and supplemental oxygen can be administered as needed. Subsequent treatment should focus on seizure management and identifying the cause. Ongoing assessment of respiratory and neurologic status remains essential.    

Option Analysis

❌ Valproic acid :
Incorrect: Valproic acid is used for long-term seizure management, not for acute seizure termination. In addition, in the setting of respiratory compromise, the priority is immediate airway protection with intubation and mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Intravenous antibiotics :
Incorrect: Administration of empiric antibiotics is indicated in suspected meningitis, which typically presents with disorientation, headache, fever, and meningeal signs. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a structural or neurologic process. Additionally, the immediate need is airway stabilization due to respiratory compromise. 
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis :
Incorrect: While lumbar puncture is essential in the evaluation of suspected meningitis, neuroimaging should be performed first in patients presenting with focal neurologic deficits or altered mental status. Additionally, in this case of respiratory failure, airway protection takes precedence. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) of the brain :
Incorrect: Neuroimaging is important to evaluate for the structural or neurologic causes of this patient’s presentation but should be deferred until the airway is secured. In the setting of acute respiratory failure, immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation are required.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of headaches. The pain is described as dull and pressure-like, typically occurring in the early morning and lasting about an hour, resolving spontaneously. The headache is usually associated with non-bloody, non-bilious emesis and visual disturbances. There is no history of seizures, loss of consciousness, fever, or neurological deficits. Birth, family, and developmental history are noncontributory, and immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Height and weight are at the 5th percentile. Bilateral papilledema is noted on fundoscopic examination. Neurological examination reveals normal strength, gait, and reflexes. Genital and breast exams reveal Tanner stage 2 pubertal development. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain reveals a heterogenous solid and cystic suprasellar mass, and a biopsy is scheduled. Which of the following additional diagnostic studies should be ordered?
questions.solution:
Suprasellar mass consistent with craniopharyngioma on brain MRI. Reproduced from; Statdx 

This 13-year-old adolescent presents with early morning headaches, vomiting, and visual disturbances. Physical examination reveals short stature, poor weight gain, delayed puberty, and papilledema. Brain MRI demonstrates a suprasellar mass consistent with craniopharyngioma. Evaluation should include measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels to assess for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.       

In a patient presenting with early morning headache and vomiting, consider a midline or posterior fossa mass. The presence of ataxia would point to a posterior fossa lesion, while delayed linear growth suggests a suprasellar mass, such as craniopharyngioma. History may include visual changes due to pressure on the optic nerve, delayed puberty, diabetes insipidus, and thyroid dysfunction. Physical exam findings can include visual field deficits, papilledema, short stature, and poor weight gain. MRI typically reveals a heterogeneous solid and cystic suprasellar mass. Diagnosis is confirmed via biopsy or surgical resection. Histologic features include stratified epithelium, multiple cysts containing thick “motor oil”-like fluid, cholesterol cysts, and keratin pearls.        

Given the suprasellar location and potential impact on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, a comprehensive endocrine evaluation is crucial. In addition to FSH and LH, growth hormone and insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels should be assessed to screen for growth hormone deficiency. Other important labs include prolactin, morning serum cortisol, adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), and free T4.   



Option Analysis

❌ Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level  :
Incorrect: Elevated AFP levels are characteristic of yolk sac tumors and immature teratomas, which can occur in the pineal or suprasellar regions. However, the combination of short stature, low weight, delayed puberty, and MRI findings in this case makes craniopharyngioma more likely. In this context, obtaining FSH and LH levels would be more appropriate. 
❌ Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level :
Incorrect: Elevated beta-hCG levels are characteristic of choriocarcinoma and embryonal cell carcinoma, which can occur in the pineal or suprasellar regions and may lead to precocious puberty. However, the combination of short stature, low weight, delayed puberty, and MRI findings in this case makes craniopharyngioma more likely. In this context, obtaining FSH and LH levels would be more appropriate. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis :
Incorrect: CSF analysis may assist in evaluating infectious or neoplastic processes, but lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with papilledema due to the risk of cerebral herniation. This patient's delayed growth and puberty with a suprasellar mass on brain MRI are consistent with craniopharyngioma. Therefore, the most appropriate diagnostic step is to obtain FSH and LH levels.  
✅ Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy  :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy can be useful for the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and peptic ulcer disease (PUD), which can present with vomiting. However, the vomiting in this case occurs in the early morning and is associated with signs of increased intracranial pressure and visual symptoms. This patient's delayed growth and puberty with a suprasellar mass on brain MRI are consistent with craniopharyngioma. Therefore, the most appropriate diagnostic step is to obtain FSH and LH levels.

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by a parent for a one-month history of early morning headaches and a wide-based, unsteady gait. These symptoms are not associated with fever or seizures. Family, birth, and developmental histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 96/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the child is alert and active. Neurological exam reveals ataxia, and fundoscopic exam shows bilateral papilledema. Strength, tone, and reflexes are normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain reveals a large mass in the posterior fossa. Gross total resection is performed, and pathology shows Homer Wright rosettes and small, round blue cells with foci of necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The 2-year-old presents with headaches, ataxia, and papilledema without hyperreflexia or clonus, along with a posterior fossa mass on MRI and histology showing Homer Wright rosettes and small, round blue cells with foci of necrosis; this presentation is consistent with medulloblastoma.         

In a young child presenting with early morning headaches, vomiting, and ataxia, a posterior fossa mass should be suspected. Neurological examination should assess for hyperreflexia and clonus, which presence may suggest a brainstem mass, such as diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG). In the absence of these findings, cerebellar or fourth ventricle tumors, such as pilocytic astrocytoma, medulloblastoma, or ependymoma, are more likely to be present. Common symptoms can include visual disturbances (e.g. double vision), facial weakness, and head tilt. Physical exam findings might include papilledema, nystagmus, cranial nerve palsies, torticollis, and hemiparesis.       

MRI confirming a posterior fossa mass should prompt a surgical evaluation and biopsy. Histologic findings of small, round blue cells with Homer Wright rosettes and foci of necrosis confirm the diagnosis of medulloblastoma.    


Option Analysis

❌ Craniopharyngioma  :
Incorrect: Craniopharyngiomas are typically suprasellar masses that present with visual disturbances, delayed growth, and endocrine dysfunction. Biopsy often shows keratin pearls and multiple cysts with thick, “motor oil”-like fluid. The clinical presentation, imaging, and biopsy findings in this patient are more consistent with medulloblastoma.  
❌ Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma  :
Incorrect: Diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas arise in the pons and commonly present with ataxia, cranial nerve palsies, and hyperreflexia or clonus. MRI typically shows a non-enhancing, diffuse, infiltrating mass in the pons. The clinical presentation, imaging, and biopsy findings in this patient are more consistent with medulloblastoma. 
❌ Ependymoma  :
Incorrect: Ependymoma can present with clinical and imaging findings similar to those in this case. However, histology typically shows perivascular pseudorosettes, not Homer Wright rosettes. The biopsy findings in this case are more consistent with medulloblastoma. 
✅ Medulloblastoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pilocytic astrocytoma :
Incorrect: Pilocystic astrocytoma can present with clinical and imaging findings similar to those in this case. However, histology typically shows compact fibrillary tissue mixed with cystic spongy areas and rosenthal fibers. The biopsy findings in this case are more consistent with medulloblastoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal eating behavior. For the past few weeks, the patient has been eating more and more. This week, the patient ate five to six meals a day and has gained 17 kg in the past two months. The patient had a craniopharyngioma surgically resected three months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is now 34 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone, growth hormone, prolactin, and cortisol levels are normal. Damage to which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with new onset hyperphagia after a recent intracranial surgery for the resection of a craniopharyngioma. Based on these findings, the patient has most likely suffered damage to the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus.  

The hypothalamus is located between the optic chiasma and the mammillary bodies and serves as the site of regulation for temperature, hunger, satiety, endocrine functions, circadian rhythm, emotion, behavior, and sexual drive. Damage to the hypothalamus occurs from tumors such as a craniopharyngiomas, radiotherapy, traumatic brain injury, infiltrative disorders,  inflammatory diseases, and surgery.  

The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus regulates blood glucose. Stimulation of the ventromedial nucleus by the hormone leptin, a product of adipose tissue, induces satiety. When the ventromedial nucleus is damaged, hyperphagia from an uncontrolled voracious appetite and hypothalamic obesity result.  



Option Analysis

❌ Lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus responds to ghrelin, which is produced by the stomach to initiate hunger and increase appetite. Injury sustained to the lateral nucleus can cause loss of appetite, anorexia, and subsequent starvation. This patient has the opposite clinical presentation.
❌ Posterior hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus increases body temperature and is activated by sympathetic input. A lesion in this region will result in poikilothermia.
❌ Suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The suprachiasmatic nucleus receives input from photosensitive cells in the retina and transmits this information to the pineal gland and other hypothalamic nuclei to regulate circadian rhythm.
❌ Paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The paraventricular nucleus produces oxytocin, which is transported to nerve terminals in the posterior pituitary and stored for eventual release. Oxytocin promotes milk ejection and uterine contraction in females.
✅ Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate dysphagia in solids and liquids. The symptoms started six months ago and have gradually worsened. She also has noticed weakness in the right shoulder for a similar period. The patient does not smoke and has no chronic conditions. Physical examination of the head and neck reveals a decreased left gag reflex, uvular deviation to the right, and atrophy of the left trapezius muscle. A head MRI is obtained, and a mass is detected. Which of the following is the most likely location of the mass?
questions.solution:
Jugular foramen syndrome is the constellation of symptoms resulting from compression of the cranial nerves emerging from the jugular foramen at the skull base.

The jugular foramen is an opening on the inferior surface of the skull between the petrous temporal bone and occipital bone. The sigmoid sinus and cranial nerves IX, X, and XI course through the jugular fossa to exit from the inferior aspect of the skull.



The glossopharyngeal nerve carries motor, sensory, and parasympathetic fibers. It aids in swallowing by supplying motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle. It also carries taste and normal sensation from the posterior third of the tongue. The vagus nerve assists in palatal elevation, speech phonation, blood pressure, and heart rate regulation. The accessory nerve is a pure motor nerve that innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
