A mass extending into the jugular foramen (e.g., glomus jugulare paraganglioma, schwannoma, meningioma) can compress cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. Jugular foramen syndrome can also develop due to non-neoplastic etiologies, including penetrating trauma, congenital conditions (e.g. primary cholesteatoma), and vascular abnormalities (e.g. internal jugular vein thrombosis).  

The clinical presentation of jugular foramen syndrome involves loss of taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue (IX), vocal cord paralysis (X), and an absent gag reflex (IX, X). In addition, patients may have weakness and atrophy of the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles (XI). Due to its location within the petrous temporal bone, pathologies affecting the jugular foramen can also cause conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. If there is a significant intracranial extension of the tumor, symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure may develop.  

Option Analysis

✅ Left jugular foramen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left internal auditory meatus:
Incorrect: Cranial nerves VII and VIII pass through the internal auditory meatus. A mass in this location would cause compression of these nerves, resulting in facial paralysis and hearing loss symptoms. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is due to compression of the cranial nerves IX, X, and XI.     
❌ Left hypoglossal canal:
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) exits the skull through the hypoglossal canal, and compression of this nerve can cause tongue paralysis. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to jugular foramen syndrome, wherein cranial nerves IX, X, and XI are compressed as they pass through the jugular foramen.
❌ Left foramen spinosum:
Incorrect: The foramen spinosum contains the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein, and meningeal branch of the mandibular foramen. Compression of these structures would not account for the symptoms experienced by this patient.
❌ Foramen magnum:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compression of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, likely at the jugular foramen. A mass in the foramen magnum would not cause compression of these cranial nerves.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to worsening occipital headache, difficulty walking, and blurred vision for the past two months. The patient reports associated nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.2°F), pulse is 40/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg. Neurologic examination demonstrates bilateral papilledema and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT-brain is demonstrated below.  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
While awaiting reassessment in the emergency department, the patient suddenly decompensates and dies. A post-mortem autopsy reveals brain herniation as the cause of death. Which of the following mechanisms of herniation most likely lead to this patient’s decompensation?
questions.solution:
A tonsillar herniation is characterized by descent of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, which compresses the medulla against the clivus/odontoid process. When the cerebellar tonsils herniate, they can compress the brainstem respiratory and cardiac centers, leading to coma and death. This type of herniation is often described as "coning,”  as the brain tissue coming down through the foramen is squeezed into a cone. Common causes of this herniation include tumors or bleeding in the posterior cranial fossa.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cingulate herniation  :
Incorrect: Cingulate (or subfalcine) herniation is the most common type of cerebral herniation and is characterized by displacement of the cingulate gyrus beneath the free edge of the falx cerebri due to elevated intracranial pressure. This patient has evidence of a posterior fossa mass and tonsillar herniation.  
❌ Transtentorial herniation  :
Incorrect: Transtentorial (or central) herniation is a type of cerebral herniation that results in the caudal displacement of the brainstem, rupture of the paramedian basilar artery branches and Duret hemorrhages.  
❌ Uncal herniation  :
Incorrect: Uncal herniation is a subtype of the herniation that results in compression of the innermost portion of the temporal lobe (the uncus) and direct compression of the oculomotor nerve.  
✅ Tonsillar herniation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transcalvarial herniation  :
Incorrect: In transcalvarial herniation, the brain herniates through a fracture or a surgical site in the skull. This type of herniation may occur during craniectomy.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a persistent ringing sensation in his right ear for the past three months. He also reports progressive hearing loss in the right ear and right-sided facial heaviness that started simultaneously. The symptoms did not respond to over-the-counter pseudoephedrine. He has no medical problems and does not take any medications. Family history is significant for hearing loss in his father requiring hearing aid at the age of 75. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right-sided facial numbness, asymmetric smile, and diminished corneal reflex in the right eye. Weber test is positive for sensorineural hearing loss on the right side. This patient's condition suggests an intracranial mass located in which of the following locations?

choices.text: In the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity
Between the cerebellum and the lateral pons

questions.solution:
This patient has right-sided sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, facial numbness, and paralysis, which is concerning for a vestibular schwannoma, the most common cerebellopontine angle (i.e. between the cerebellum and pons) tumor in adults.  

Vestibular schwannomas arise from the Schwann cells of the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). These benign tumors often compress the nerves originating from the cerebellopontine angle, including CN V and VII. Symptoms can vary based on the pattern of nerve involvement and can include:  
 
  1.  The cochlear part of CN VIII: Sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus (ear ringing). 
  2.  The vestibular part of CN VIII: Vertigo, disequilibrium, and nystagmus.  
  3.  The facial nerve (CN VII): Paralysis of the muscles of facial expression, loss of taste in the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, and hyperacusis (paralysis of the stapedius). 
  4.  Trigeminal nerve (CN V): Loss of sensation around the mouth and nose, loss of corneal reflex, and paralysis of the muscles of mastication. 

Option Analysis

❌ Above the diaphragma sellae:
Incorrect: Craniopharyngiomas are typically located in the suprasellar region. Patients usually present with signs and symptoms of hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction and changes in vision due to compression of the optic chiasm (e.g. bitemporal hemianopsia), none of which are seen in this patient. 
❌ Over the lateral hemispheric fissure:
Incorrect: Meningiomas arising from meningo-epithelial cells of arachnoid mater are commonly found over the lateral hemispheric fissure and in the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity. They usually present with headaches, focal neurological deficits, or seizures.
❌ In the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity:
Incorrect: Meningiomas usually arise in the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity. This patient’s findings are localized to CN V, CN VII, and CN VIII, making a mass at the cerebellopontine angle more likely.
✅ Between the cerebellum and the lateral pons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ In the dorsal midbrain:
Incorrect: Pineal gland tumors (e.g. germ cell tumors) are found in the dorsal midbrain. They usually present in the pediatric population with signs of increased intracranial pressure secondary to obstructive hydrocephalus and Parinaud syndrome (i.e. upward gaze palsy).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate dysphonia and dysphagia with solids and liquids. The patient’s symptoms started a month ago and have been progressively worsening. He has had difficulty drinking water and frequently experiences associated regurgitation and coughing. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals palatal deviation towards the right side and an absent gag reflex. MRI of the brain shows a mass. Which of the following structures is most likely affected by this mass?
questions.solution:
Bulbar palsy is a lower motor neuron defect that arises from injuries to the nucleus ambiguus.

The nucleus ambiguus is a group of motor neurons situated in the reticular formation of the medulla oblongata. The emerging fibers from the nucleus ambiguus give rise to cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, which travel to ipsilateral somatic muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. These muscles are responsible for generating speech and swallowing. The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) plays a role in swallowing by innervating the stylopharyngeus muscle. The vagus nerve innervates the palatal, pharyngeal, and laryngeal muscles. The spinal accessory nerve innervates the cranial portion of the laryngeal muscles.  

Bulbar palsy is most often caused by ischemic stroke and tumors. Other less common causes include degenerative disorders (e.g. ALS), autoimmune diseases (e.g. Guillain-Barre syndrome), and hereditary conditions (e.g. Kennedy disease).    

Clinical features arise due to isolated paralysis of the palate, pharynx, and larynx. They include dysphagia to both solids and liquids, hoarseness, aspiration of secretions, nasal regurgitation, dysphonia, dysarthria, and slurred speech. The uvula often deviates to the side contralateral to the causative lesion on examination. The gag reflex is often absent. 



In contrast, pseudobulbar palsy is an upper motor neuron defect involving cranial nerves IX, X, and XI (damage to the connections between the cortex and medulla) that presents with symptoms similar to bulbar palsy. Reflexes are normal or more prominent in pseudobulbar palsy. In addition, atrophy and fasciculations are absent. Lastly, pseudobulbar palsy is characterized by emotional lability, which is not seen in bulbar palsy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Left nucleus ambiguus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left cerebral cortex :
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, dysphonia, palatal deviation, and loss of the gag reflex. These findings are suggestive of bulbar palsy, which is a lower motor neuron lesion. In contrast, lesions in the cerebral cortex would be classified as upper motor neuron lesions.
❌ Corticobulbar tract bilaterally :
Incorrect: Pseudobulbar palsy is caused by a lesion affecting the bilateral corticobulbar tracts. However, unlike bulbar palsy, pseudobulbar palsy is not associated with an absent gag reflex. In addition, pseudobulbar palsy is associated with emotional lability, which is not noted in this patient. 
❌ Right cerebral cortex :
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, dysphonia, palatal deviation, and loss of the gag reflex. These findings are suggestive of bulbar palsy, which is a lower motor neuron lesion. In contrast, lesions in the cerebral cortex would be classified as upper motor neuron lesions.
❌ Right nucleus ambiguus :
Incorrect: The uvula deviates towards the contralateral side in patients with bulbar palsy. This patient has rightwards uvula deviation, which means the causative lesion is on the left side.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician to evaluate recurrent tripping and falling over the past two months. The patient states that he loses his balance easily and finds it difficult to walk in narrow spaces, such as the school hallway. He reports difficulty sleeping for the same duration. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies. Physical examination demonstrates bilateral papilledema, impaired upward gaze, and bilateral eyelid retraction. A brain mass is suspected, and an MRI brain is ordered.  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org  
Which of the following structures is most likely affected by this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ataxia, insomnia, downward gaze, and nystagmus consistent with Parinaud syndrome. This condition is classically associated with a tumor of the pineal gland.

Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome refers to a cluster of eye movement abnormalities characterized by limitation of upward gaze and downward gaze preference, bilateral eyelid lid retraction, and light-near dissociation (i.e. pupils react to accommodation but not to light). This combination of abnormalities manifests with a conjugate downward gaze, referred to as the "setting-sun" sign. These eye movement deficits are secondary to compression of the pretectal region of the midbrain, which in young patients often occurs due to tumors of the pineal gland.  

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Suprasellar germinomas are a less common cause of germinoma than pinealomas. They are more likely to present with endocrinopathies due to their proximity to the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. Moreover, suprasellar germinomas do not result in Parinaud syndrome.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Damage to the thalamus by hemorrhage or an intracranial mass would present with contralateral hemisensory loss, behavioral changes, and language deficits.  
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: Pontine tumors or hemorrhage can result in ‘locked in’ syndrome, which presents with spastic quadriplegia and paralysis of most cranial nerves with preserved consciousness and eye movement.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Cerebellar lesions usually present with limb and truncal ataxia, intention tremor, and nystagmus.

questions.text: A 17-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to behavioral concerns. The patient has been less interactive with family members and more irritable for six weeks. During his last check-up one year ago, the patient was otherwise healthy. Since then, the patient has not achieved new milestones in speech, gross motor, or fine motor development. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 79/min, respirations are 28/min and blood pressure is 105/55 mm Hg. The patient does not maintain eye contact. The anterior fontanelle is closed. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination is unremarkable. The skin is pink and well perfused. Growth charting demonstrates a rapidly enlarging head circumference. A CT scan of the brain reveals a mass lesion, enlarged lateral and third ventricles, and a normally sized fourth ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic site pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an enlarging head circumference, behavioral changes, and delayed developmental milestones, suggesting hydrocephalus.

In hydrocephalus, impaired outflow leads to an increase in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume,  dilation of the ventricles, and compression of surrounding brain tissue. Normally, CSF is produced by the choroid plexus, flows from the lateral, through the third and fourth ventricles, and ultimately to the subarachnoid space for reabsorption. The narrowest portion of the ventricular system is the cerebral aqueduct, also called the aqueduct of Sylvius, where it drains CSF from the third to the fourth ventricle. The cerebral aqueduct is the most common site of obstruction that may result in hydrocephalus.

The cerebral aqueduct can be blocked by cellular debris formed from intraventricular hemorrhage, bacterial or fungal infections, as well as tumors of the midbrain or pinealomas. Clinically, hydrocephalus can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, papilledema, behavioral changes, coma, and even death.



Option Analysis

❌ Arachnoid villi  :
Incorrect: Inflammation or fibrosis of arachnoid villi can impair CSF absorption. This results in communicating hydrocephalus with global ventricular dilation and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). This patient’s fourth ventricle is normal in size, suggestive of a distal blockage to CSF flow.  
✅ Cerebral aqueduct  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Interventricular foramina of Monro  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the interventricular foramina of Monro causes enlargement of the lateral ventricles, in contrast to the enlarged lateral and third ventricles observed in this patient.  
❌ Lateral foramen of Luschka  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the lateral foramen of Luschka causes enlargement of all four ventricles. This patient’s fourth ventricle is of normal size.  
❌ Medial foramen of Magendie  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the medial foramen of Magendie causes enlargement of all four ventricles. This patient’s fourth ventricle is of normal size.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that lasted 30 seconds. The patient’s partner endorses increased difficulty with ambulation for the past several days. The patient had two instances where they lost control of their bladder without seizing. The patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears confused but is arousable. Neurological examination is significant for motor strength of 1/5 in the lower extremities bilaterally. Motor strength in the upper extremities is 5/5. MRI of the brain is shown below. Compression of which of the following areas is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org

choices.text: Medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule)
Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
This patient presents with radiologic findings of a space-occupying lesion consistent with a parasagittal meningioma. In addition, there is evidence of urinary incontinence, seizures, and bilateral lower extremity weakness, which can be due to compression of the medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule).   

The paracentral lobule is an area of the brain located on the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres that lies in close proximity to the falx cerebri and surrounds the indentation produced by the central sulcus. Functionally, it is involved in cerebral control of both urination and defecation. It also houses motor and sensory innervation of the contralateral lower extremities. Thus a space-occupying lesion of this area (e.g. parasagittal meningioma) can cause urinary incontinence, seizures, and bilateral lower extremity weakness.    

The paracentral lobule is supplied by the branches of the anterior cerebral artery, so occlusion of the ACA results in hemiparesis and hemisensory loss in the contralateral lower extremity and urinary incontinence. Corresponding ischemic involvement of the anterior frontal and parietal lobes results in apathy, inability to accurately identify objects, and personality changes.    



Option Analysis

✅ Medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Damage to Broca’s area manifests with non-fluent speech with intact comprehension and impaired repetition. Bladder incontinence is not typical for a lesion in this area.
❌ Premotor cortex:
Incorrect: The premotor cortex stores and processes information regarding past activity as well as integration of sensory and motor information for planning of future voluntary movements. A lesion of the premotor cortex would not explain this patient’s presentation with lower extremity weakness, urinary incontinence, and seizure.
❌ Prefrontal cortex:
Incorrect: The prefrontal cortex is responsible for executive functions, such as decision making, judgment, and reasoning; it also regulates depth of feeling. Damage to the prefrontal cortex leads to disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Arcuate fasciculus:
Incorrect: The arcuate fasciculus is a bundle of nerve fibers between Broca’s and Wernicke’s area. Conduction aphasia results from injury or a lesion involving the arcuate fasciculus. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech and preserved comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech contains frequent phonemic errors.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a progressive, constant headache over the past week, which is associated with frequent vomiting. The patient has also had abdominal pain for the past three months. He has been evaluated by his primary care physician and a gastroenterologist, and his symptoms have persisted despite treatment with an H2 receptor antagonist and proton pump inhibitor. On review of systems, he endorses fatigue and an unintentional 13-pound weight loss. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, he appears frail and uncomfortable, but he is alert and converses easily without confusion. Neurologic examination reveals impaired extraocular movements, right facial droop, rightward deviation of the tongue, and horizontal diplopia. Which of the following diagnostic tests would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of a brainstem lesion, including impaired extraocular movements, facial droop, and tongue deviation, in the setting of a progressive headache, fatigue, and unintentional weight loss. This combination of findings is highly concerning for an underlying malignancy with leptomeningeal carcinomatosis. The definitive diagnostic test for this diagnosis is cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cytology.

Patients with a suspected brainstem lesion affecting cranial nerves in the midbrain, pons, and medulla may have an underlying meningeal process. Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis should be considered in patients with known or suspected malignancy and progressive neurologic deficits, whereas subarachnoid hemorrhage typically presents with a sudden, severe headache and neurologic deficits. A non-contrast CT of the brain can reveal blood in the subarachnoid space in cases of subarachnoid hemorrhage. In patients with leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, the presence of malignant cells on CSF cytology confirms the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cytology:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient's clinical picture is consistent with a subacute brainstem lesion, and his weight loss and fatigue raise concerns for an underlying malignancy. Although imaging can aid in the evaluation of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, a contrast-enhanced MRI is much more sensitive than a non-contrast CT. But ultimately, CSF cytology is the most specific test for confirming the diagnosis.
❌ Upper endoscopy (i.e. esophagogastroduodenoscopy, or EGD):
Incorrect: Although the patient’s vomiting, abdominal pain, unintentional weight loss, and fatigue raise concern for an underlying gastrointestinal malignancy, his more acute neurological deficits point toward a brainstem lesion. CSF cytology would provide confirmation of the diagnosis of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis.
❌ Complete blood count (CBC) with differential:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a subacute brainstem lesion. While his gastrointestinal symptoms, unintentional weight loss, and fatigue raise concern for an underlying gastrointestinal malignancy, a CBC is nonspecific and does not provide confirmatory evidence for leptomeningeal carcinomatosis. CSF cytology is a more definitive test for this diagnosis.
❌ Esophageal pH probe test:
Incorrect: An esophageal pH probe test is used to assess acid reflux, not central nervous system pathology. This patient's gastrointestinal symptoms, unintentional weight loss, and fatigue are more suggestive of an underlying malignancy, and the primary concern is leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, which is best confirmed through CSF cytology.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the primary care clinic by a family member for evaluation of confusion. Over the past week, the patient has become unable to recognize familiar faces but can identify family members by voice and mannerisms. There has been no fever, but the patient reports vertigo described as dizziness and has experienced several falls. Medical history is notable for small cell lung cancer with known metastases to both adrenal glands. The patient is not currently receiving treatment and takes no medications. There is no alcohol or substance use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. On examination, there is mild right-sided weakness and dysarthria, with an inability to recognize famous faces. Which of the following diagnostic tests would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with contrast
Computerized tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast

questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with agnosia, specifically prosopagnosia, which is the inability to recognize faces. This is a cortical sign that localizes to the bilateral fusiform gyri. Given her known cancer diagnosis, the most helpful test to confirm a suspected metastatic lesion is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with intravenous contrast.       

Patients with cortical lesions exhibit symptoms based on the region of the brain involved. The differential diagnosis can often be narrowed by the dominant presenting symptom, such as aphasia, anopsia, agnosia, or neglect. On the other hand, subcortical lesions typically present with motor symptoms, hemisensory loss, or cognitive and behavioral changes. When agnosia is the primary symptom, it is important to identify the specific type. The combination of finger agnosia, acalculia, agraphia, and left-right disorientation suggests a lesion in the dominant (usually left) angular gyrus. In contrast, prosopagnosia is associated with bilateral lesions of the fusiform gyri in the occipitotemporal region.       

Neuroimaging is essential for confirming the diagnosis. MRI, with and without intravenous contrast, can help characterize the lesion and differentiate between potential causes.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast:
Incorrect: CT without contrast has limited sensitivity for detecting cortical or posterior fossa lesions, especially in the setting of subacute neurologic symptoms. MRI with contrast provides superior visualization of potential metastases or paraneoplastic processes affecting the temporal or occipital lobes. 
❌ Neuropsychological testing:
Incorrect: While neuropsychological testing can characterize cognitive deficits, it is not the initial diagnostic step in the evaluation of acute-onset prosopagnosia and focal neurologic findings. Structural imaging is required to assess for metastatic or other brain lesions. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the chest:
Incorrect: The primary malignancy has already been diagnosed. Evaluation should focus on the current neurologic symptoms, which raise concern for brain metastases. 
❌ Sputum cytology:
Incorrect: Cytology is used to establish a primary lung cancer diagnosis but is not useful in a patient with already diagnosed small cell lung cancer. Given the acute neurologic findings, brain imaging is the appropriate next step.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because he is concerned regarding an upcoming eight-hour-long road trip to Niagara Falls. The patient frequently develops nausea and dizziness when riding in a car for more than 30 minutes. He has vomited twice over the past month while riding in a car. His symptoms significantly impair his ability to participate in long trips with friends. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver is negative, and gait is normal. Strength and range of motion are full and symmetric bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. The patient inquires if there is a medication that he can take during the road trip to help mitigate his symptoms. Which of the following medications will most effectively manage this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Muscarinic antagonists prevent the effects of acetylcholine (ACh) by blocking its binding to muscarinic receptors on effector cells at parasympathetic (and sympathetic cholinergic) neuroeffector junctions in the peripheral ganglia and the central nervous system (CNS).  

Scopolamine prevents the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors in the vomiting center of the brainstem. This property effectively prevents motion sickness during travel or nausea and vomiting after surgery.  

Other antimuscarinic antagonists include:  

  •  The prototypical medication atropine, which can induce pupillary dilation, treat bradycardia, nocturnal enuresis, and reverse organophosphate poisoning. 
  •  Oxybutynin is given in urge incontinence 
  •  Ipratropium and tiotropium are used for COPD and asthma. 
  •  Benztropine and trihexyphenidyl are used to treat tremors in Parkinson disease. 
  •  Hyoscyamine and dicyclomine are used as antispasmodics to manage symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome. 
  • Glycopyrrolate, which can be used preoperatively to reduce airway secretions. Its oral administration 


Option Analysis

❌ Benztropine:
Incorrect: Benztropine and trihexyphenidyl are muscarinic antagonists mainly active in the striatum. They can be given to patients with Parkinson disease to restore the balance of cholinergic and dopaminergic signaling, thereby improving tremors.  
❌ Glycopyrrolate:
Incorrect: Glycopyrrolate is a muscarinic antagonist that acts on the gastrointestinal and respiratory tract. Intravenous glycopyrrolate can be administered preoperatively to reduce airway secretions. Its oral administration helps reduce drooling.  
✅ Scopolamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oxybutynin:
Incorrect: Oxybutynin works on muscarinic receptors in the bladder, where the drug decreases detrusor muscle spasms prevents urge incontinence or involuntary urination due to an overactive bladder.  
❌ Ipratropium:
Incorrect: Ipratropium and tiotropium are muscarinic antagonists that work as bronchodilators. They are usually given via inhalers. The medications enter the lungs and bind to muscarinic receptors on the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles, causing smooth muscle relaxation and bronchial dilation. These properties make them effective in relieving chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a syncopal episode that occurred at home while gardening. According to the patient, he stood up from gardening, immediately felt light-headed, and fell to the ground. The patient’s spouse reports that he awoke immediately following the fall and seemed slightly disoriented, but was able to answer questions appropriately. He did not hit his head and there was no shaking movement of the limbs during the incident. The patient had a recent gastrointestinal illness with vomiting and diarrhea that ended this morning. He has a past medical history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. Medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, and losartan. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 20/min. His blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg while seated and drops to 102/62 mmHg after standing for two minutes. His heart rate increases from 68/min while seated to 82/min upon standing. The patient is awake, alert, and oriented, with normal speech. Dry mucous membranes are noted. Heart and lung examinations are normal. Strength is 5/5 in the upper and lower extremities, and gait is normal. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with typical symptoms of orthostatic hypotension, including light-headedness and syncope upon standing. This older patient may have autonomic dysfunction that may have been further exacerbated by fluid depletion (e.g. dry mucous membranes) from his recent gastrointestinal illness, leading to orthostatic hypotension. Fluid replacement is the best next step in management.

Syncope, defined as a transient, self-limited loss of consciousness, is caused by a temporary decrease in cerebral blood flow. Based on the underlying cause, syncope can be categorized into several types. These include cardiogenic syncope caused by heart-related issues; reflex-mediated syncope triggered by various stimuli like neck pressure; syncope due to orthostatic hypotension; and neurologic syncope, which is associated with neurological conditions. If a patient presents with a chief concern suggesting syncope, an ABCDE assessment should be performed to determine if they are unstable or stable, followed by a systematic investigation to determine the most likely cause. The normal physiologic response to standing up with blood pooling in the legs is an increase in heart rate and constriction of blood vessels. This is blunted by orthostatic hypotension resulting in decreased cerebral blood flow and syncope. Etiologies of orthostatic hypotension include medications (e.g., vasodilators, inotropic/chronotropic blockade, diuretics), autonomic dysfunction (e.g., advanced age, neurodegenerative disease), and hypovolemia (e.g., fluid restriction, GI losses, fever).

Orthostatic hypotension is a common cause of syncope, particularly in older adults. Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a decrease in systolic blood pressure of at least 20 mmHg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg within 2-5 minutes of standing. Treatment depends largely on the underlying etiology but can include modifying postural transition, such as rising slowly when standing, increasing fluid and salt intake, or discontinuing/decreasing the dose of causative medications. This patient should receive intravenous fluids, as he appears clinically hypovolemic. Consideration could be given to lowering the dose of his beta-blocker or discontinuing the medication, as it is likely to be a contributing factor.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increase dosage of losartan:
Incorrect: Increasing the dosage of antihypertensives (e.g. losartan) in a patient with orthostatic hypotension could further exacerbate the patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Cardiology consult for pacemaker placement:
Incorrect: Pacemaker placement is not indicated in this scenario as the patient’s history, symptoms, and ECG findings are consistent with orthostatic hypotension, and not with bradyarrhythmia or heart block that would warrant such an intervention.  
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: An MRI of the brain is not indicated in this scenario, as this patient’s history and physical examination are more consistent with orthostatic hypotension than an acute stroke or other brain pathology.  
❌ Transthoracic echocardiography:
Incorrect: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is typically used to assess structural cardiac abnormalities. While TTE is important in evaluating certain causes of syncope, it is not indicated in this case where the clinical presentation is most consistent with orthostatic hypotension.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion, disorientation, and slurred speech. His partner reports that he has been increasingly forgetful over the past few weeks and has had difficulty with daily tasks. She also mentions that he has been more fatigued than usual, and his abdomen has become distended. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and has multiple glasses of vodka nightly. He was diagnosed with cirrhosis two years ago. He has not returned to the clinic for follow-up care or treatment. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 128/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the patient is drowsy but awakens easily. He is oriented to person only. There is a bilateral scleral icterus. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light. Spider angiomas are present across the chest. Extraocular muscles are intact and there are no abnormalities in eye movement. Asterixis is present. The abdomen is distended with a positive fluid wave. There is no tenderness to palpation. There are no focal neurologic deficits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with lethargy, disorientation, slurred speech, and asterixis in the setting of cirrhosis with abdominal distension and possible spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), likely has hepatic encephalopathy. He has signs of chronic liver disease, including jaundice and spider angioma. He also has findings consistent with ascites. This patient has a distended abdomen with a fluid wave and paracentesis should be performed to diagnose spontaneous bacterial peritonitis that may have precipitated hepatic encephalopathy. Findings of an elevated serum ammonia level would support the diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy. 

The diagnostic workup for an adult with altered mental status (AMS) begins with a rapid assessment of vital signs and basic laboratory tests, including blood glucose, electrolytes, and arterial blood gas to quickly identify and correct life-threatening conditions such as hypoglycemia, hypoxia, or hypercapnia. Patients with Hypoglycemia typically present with confusion, diaphoresis, and tachycardia, and it is rapidly reversible with glucose administration. Patients with Hypoxia or hypercapnia, often seen in conjunction with respiratory disorders, may present with confusion, cyanosis, or lethargy, and low oxygen or elevated carbon dioxide levels on blood gas analysis can confirm the diagnosis. Toxins and medications can cause AMS, and symptoms will differ based on the substance ingested. detailed history, toxicology screen, and careful review of the patient’s medication list can help make the diagnosis. Patients suspected of having Central nervous system disorders, such as stroke or meningitis, require imaging and possibly lumbar puncture. Metabolic disorders like uremia or hepatic encephalopathy are diagnosed via a combination of laboratory abnormalities and clinical findings. The table below shows some of the common causes of AMS and their associated findings.   

Option Analysis

❌ Wernicke encephalopathy:
Incorrect: Wernicke encephalopathy is associated with thiamine deficiency and can be seen in patients with chronic alcohol use. Patients present with encephalopathy, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. This patient does not have ophthalmoplegia but does have signs of chronic liver disease, ascites, and encephalopathy which point to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) as a precipitant of hepatic encephalopathy. 
❌ Subdural hematoma:
Incorrect: Patients who have a subdural hematoma typically present with a history of head trauma, followed by gradual onset of headache, confusion, and focal neurological deficits. This patient has not experienced trauma and has no focal neurological findings, making a subdural hematoma unlikely.  
❌ Delirium tremens:
Incorrect: Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by agitation, tremors, hallucinations, and autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension). This patient does not exhibit these symptoms and has no history of recent alcohol cessation. 
✅ Hepatic encephalopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dementia:
Incorrect: Dementia typically has a more gradual course. This patient has a subacute presentation of altered mental status more likely due to hypercalcemia due to lung malignancy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old individual presents to a neurologist for follow up after having multiple syncopal episodes at home. The patient is frustrated by not having a diagnosis despite multiple visits to the emergency department, all of which demonstrated normal cardiac, metabolic, and urinary markers. During these visits, the patient was provided with intravenous fluids without resolution in symptoms. The patient reports episodes of dizziness and lightheadedness when going from a sitting to a standing position. The patient’s sitting blood pressure is 127/82 mmHg. Blood pressure immediately upon standing is 76/44 mmHg with reproduction of symptoms. Physical examination is otherwise noncontributory. The patient has been prescribed counterpressure maneuvers in the past without improvement in symptomatology. The decision is made to initiate a medication. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication used to treat this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with dysautonomia, or chronic idiopathic autonomic insufficiency, given the postural hypotension and otherwise negative cardiac and metabolic workup. The most appropriate treatment for the orthostatic effects of this condition is midodrine, a pure α1 agonist.     

Patients with autonomic insufficiency or poor sympathetic tone are unable to maintain adequate vascular smooth muscle contraction with position changes, resulting in pooling of venous blood and a decrease in cerebral perfusion. Midodrine, a relatively new sympathomimetic, carries agonistic effects on α1 receptors, resulting in an increase in baseline sympathetic tone, thus off-setting these symptoms. Care should be taken when prescribing this medication to those with hypertension while lying flat as it may worsen a patient’s baseline hypertension.  

Option Analysis

✅ α1 agonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ α1, α2, ß1, and ß3 agonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of norepinephrine. Midodrine is a pure alpha agonist.  
❌ D1, α1, α2, ß1, and ß3 agonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of dopamine, which carries similar properties to norepinephrine but also agonizes the D1 receptor. Activation of this receptor relaxes renal vascular smooth muscle and activates the direct pathway of the striatum in the brain. It is not routinely used in clinical practice due to its propensity towards fatal cardiac arrhythmias.  
❌ α1, α2 agonism:
Incorrect: α1, and α2 agonists include medications such as phenylephrine. Midodrine only carries α1 activity.  
❌ ß2 agonism:
Incorrect: Medications such as albuterol or salmeterol are pure ß2 agonists, which are not indicated in patients with dysautonomia or autonomic insufficiency.

questions.text: A medication is currently under study in rat models that is found to have potent cardiovascular effects, including increasing the heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output at intermediate doses. Further investigation of this medication reveals it carries structural homogeneity with a neurotransmitter responsible for activating the direct pathway of the striatum of the brain. This medication has also been demonstrated to carry which of the following physiologic properties?

choices.text: Increased water reabsorption in the collecting tubules

questions.solution:
This medication under study is shown to increase the heart rate, cardiac contractility, and blood pressure while also activating the direct nigro-striatal pathway. This is consistent with dopamine. When administered peripherally and at lower doses, it carries significant sympathomimetic effects. Notably, it causes dilation of renal arteries.     

Dopamine, now seldom used in modern clinical practice, was historically used for patients in shock with concomitant renal failure due to its agonistic effects on D1 receptors. This includes causing splanchnic and renal vasodilation. As a sympathomimetic, dopamine carries alpha and beta effects, resulting in the aforementioned effects on cardiac function. Notably, alpha effects tend to predominate at higher doses, resulting in vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure. Additional uses for dopamine include treatment of unstable bradycardia and shocks (e.g. cardiogenic, refractory distributive).    

Primary toxicities of dopamine include cardiovascular disturbance and arrhythmias. Central nervous system side effects are not observed when dopamine is given parenterally due to minimal penetration through the blood-brain barrier.  

Option Analysis

✅ Dilation of renal arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Laryngospasm:
Incorrect: Laryngospasm is a known side effect of the NMDA-receptor antagonist ketamine. It is not a known side effect of dopamine.  
❌ Increased water reabsorption in the collecting tubules:
Incorrect: Increased water reabsorption in the collecting tubules of the kidneys is one of the known effects of vasopressin via agonism at V2 receptors. Dopamine does not carry effects on V2 receptors.  
❌ Increased gastric acid secretion:
Incorrect: Increased gastric acid secretion is mediated via H1 receptors, which are not affected by dopamine.  
❌ Dystonia:
Incorrect: Anti-dopaminergic agents, such as benztropine, may precipitate dystonic reactions, but dopamine does not.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the clinic after experiencing two episodes of “fainting” in the past month. She states that both episodes occurred while she was standing in line at the grocery store, when she suddenly started feeling warm, sweaty, and lightheaded just prior to losing consciousness. Each time, she regained consciousness within a minute and felt slightly nauseous, but not confused. Her past medical history is significant for depression and hypertension and her medications include sertraline and amlodipine. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg while supine and 124/82 mmHg while standing. Cardiovascular examination is normal, with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ST or T wave abnormalities. Echocardiography reveals a normal left ventricular size and normal ejection fraction. What additional history is most likely to be associated with this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Family history of sudden cardiac death
Similar episodes triggered by emotional distress

questions.solution:
This middle-aged patient who is presenting with a brief loss of consciousness following a prolonged period of standing, as well as prodromal symptoms (e.g., lightheadedness, feeling of warmth, diaphoresis) most likely experienced episodes of vasovagal syncope.

Vasovagal syncope is often triggered by emotional stress, pain, or prolonged standing. It is characterized by a transient loss of consciousness and muscle tone due to a sudden decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, leading to reduced cerebral perfusion. The patient's 2 documented episodes occurred while standing in line at the grocery store, suggesting a potential trigger from standing or a stress-related event. Classic prodromal symptoms associated with syncope and presyncope, particularly the vasovagal form of reflex syncope, include lightheadedness, a feeling of warmth or cold, sweating, palpitations, pallor, nausea, visual blurring, and diminution of hearing and/or occurrence of unusual (often "whooshing") sounds.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Recent uptitration of amlodipine:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is not significantly low and there is no evidence of orthostatic hypotension. This patient with loss of consciousness following prolonged standing and associated with a prodrome most likely has vasovagal syncope.  
❌ Family history of sudden cardiac death:
Incorrect: Sudden cardiac death can be caused by arrhythmias, such as ventricular fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia. This patient's normal cardiovascular examination, ECG, and echocardiography findings make a primary cardiac cause less likely, and her prodromal symptoms are more suggestive of vasovagal syncope.  
✅ Similar episodes triggered by emotional distress:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Frequent migraines:
Incorrect: Certain neurologic conditions may predispose patients to syncope, including seizure disorders, migraine headaches, Parkinson’s disease, autonomic failure, as well as strokes. However, this patient’s prodromal symptoms are more suggestive of vasovagal syncope.  
❌ Exertional chest pain:
Incorrect: Exertional chest pain would be suggestive of a cardiac cause, such as ischemic heart disease; however, the patient's normal cardiac examination, ECG, and echocardiography findings make this less likely. This patient with loss of consciousness following prolonged standing and associated with a prodrome most likely has vasovagal syncope.

questions.text: A newborn girl is born at 40.4 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery complicated by prolonged labor and vacuum extraction. The pregnancy was complicated by diet-controlled gestational diabetes in the mother. Following delivery, the infant appears vigorous and Apgars are 8 and 9. After spending time with the mother, the newborn is brought to the nursery for evaluation by the pediatrician. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 148/min, respirations are 42/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Birth weight is 4400 grams. On physical examination, the infant appears slightly fussy. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The upper right arm is adducted and internally rotated and the forearm is extended with the elbow pronated and the wrist flexed. Pulses are 2+ and capillary refill is < 2 seconds. No crepitus is appreciated over the clavicles. Radiographs are obtained, and no obvious deformity is noted. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Consult social work due to concern for non-accidental trauma
Order magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine

questions.solution:
This infant who is large for gestational age and born via delivery complicated by prolonged labor and vacuum extraction is noted to have the right upper arm adducted and internally rotated and the forearm extended with the elbow pronated and the wrist flexed (see image below). The history and physical exam findings are consistent with Erb palsy, which is a brachial plexus palsy that can occur with traumatic deliveries. Increased birth weight, maternal diabetes, and prolonged labor increase the risk of Erb palsy. Once a fracture is ruled out, the first step in management is to start physical therapy.       

 Infants who are born via complicated deliveries should be evaluated for birth injuries. A focused history and physical should be performed to make the appropriate diagnosis. Some injuries, such as cephalohematomas, soft tissue injuries, and clavicle fractures, require only supportive care and time to heal. Other injuries, such as long bone fractures and intracranial bleeds, may require invasive interventions such as surgery. Brachial plexus palsies are managed with conservative measures, such as physical and occupational therapy. Severe cases that fail to improve with time and therapy may require surgical intervention.   



Image courtesy of Openi

Option Analysis

✅ Consult physical therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Consult social work due to concern for non-accidental trauma:
Incorrect: This infant has Erb palsy, which is a known complication of newborn deliveries and not from non-accidental trauma. Physical therapy should be initiated to improve the infant’s range of motion.   
❌ No intervention is necessary:
Incorrect: This infant has Erb palsy, which is a known complication of newborn deliveries. Physical therapy should be started to improve the infant’s range of motion. 
❌ Splint the right arm:
Incorrect: This infant has Erb palsy, which is a known complication of newborn deliveries. Splints are occasionally needed to prevent contractures, but the first step in management is starting physical therapy to improve the infant’s range of motion. 
❌ Order magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine:
Incorrect: This infant has Erb palsy, which is due to an injury at C5 and C6 during delivery. Although radiographs are often performed to rule out fractures, MRIs are generally not necessary. Physical therapy should be started early to improve the infant’s range of motion.

questions.text:
A baby girl is born via vaginal delivery. Immediately after delivery, the baby is evaluated in the warmer and Apgars are 8 and 9. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 138/min, respirations are 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the anterior fontanelle is open and flat. There is a noticeable asymmetry of the face when the infant is crying with the mouth drawn to the right side and loss of the left nasolabial fold and drooping of the lower face on the left. Cardiopulmonary, abdominal, and extremity examinations are normal. Which of the following is most likely to have caused these findings? 



Image courtesy of Openi

choices.text: Premature delivery at < 37 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
This infant is born via vaginal delivery and is noted to have asymmetry of the face when crying with the mouth drawn to the right side and loss of the left nasolabial fold and drooping of the lower face on the left. These findings are consistent with left facial nerve palsy. Forceps delivery increases the risk of facial nerve palsy in newborns.       

Newborns are at higher risk for a birth injury when there is prolonged labor, instrumental delivery, malpresentation, macrosomia, shoulder dystocia, and preterm delivery. On physical examination, careful evaluation of the head is important after a complicated delivery. Benign causes of scalp edema include cephalohematomas and caput succedaneum. Traumatic deliveries can cause more severe head injuries like linear skull fractures, subdural hematomas, subgaleal hemorrhages, and subarachnoid hemorrhages.       

In addition to traumatic head injuries, nerve, soft tissue, and skeletal injuries can occur as a result of birth trauma. Nerve injuries include facial nerve palsy and brachial plexus injury. Soft tissue injuries include abrasions, ecchymosis, and subcutaneous fat necrosis. Clavicle and long bone fractures often present with decreased movement of the affected limb. Occasionally there will be an obvious deformity, tenderness, or overlying crepitus.   

Option Analysis

✅ Forceps delivery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Birth weight > 4000 grams :
Incorrect: This infant has facial nerve palsy, which is most often caused by forceps delivery. Increased birth weight does not put infants at increased risk for this condition at delivery. 
❌ Twin gestation:
Incorrect: This patient has facial nerve palsy, which is most often caused by forceps delivery. A twin pregnancy does not put newborns at increased risk for facial nerve palsy.  
❌ Rupture of membranes > 16 hours:
Incorrect: This patient has facial nerve palsy, which is most often caused by forceps delivery. Prolonged rupture of membranes puts newborns at risk for infections but does not increase the risk of facial nerve palsy.  
❌ Premature delivery at < 37 weeks of gestation:
Incorrect: This patient has facial nerve palsy, which is most often caused by forceps delivery. Premature delivery before 37 weeks of gestation does not increase the risk of developing facial nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for follow-up regarding facial pain. The patient states, “The symptoms have become so bothersome, I can’t sleep at night and none of the medications I’m taking are working.” The patient reports intermittent stabbing pain along the left side of her face below the eye brought on by brushing her teeth or putting makeup on. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates reproducible pain with light tapping of the upper teeth. Tapping of the lower teeth does not elicit pain. Which of the following nerves is implicated in the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of trigeminal neuralgia, a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution (CN V). This patient’s pain is localized to CN V's maxillary nerve branch (V2).

Trigeminal neuralgia is a poorly understood condition but is thought to be due to trigeminal nerve root compression. Clinically, this disease presents as recurrent, sudden onset stabbing pain along the trigeminal nerve's V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) branches, with onset triggered by minor stimuli such as touch, wind, or chewing food. Trigeminal neuralgia is a unilateral condition; however, it can occur bilaterally in usual cases, typically caused by multiple sclerosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Maxillary nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mandibular nerve:
Incorrect: The mandibular nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication. While this branch of the trigeminal nerve may also be implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia, this patient’s exam suggests disease limited to the maxillary nerve branch.  
❌ Ophthalmic nerve:
Incorrect: V1 supplies sensory function to the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, the nose. It is not commonly implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia (<5% of cases).  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It is not implicated in the pathogenesis of trigeminal neuralgia.  
❌ Glossopharyngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Motor function of cranial nerve IX or the glossopharyngeal nerve includes innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx during speaking and swallowing.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate facial pain. The patient states she has paroxysms of severe electric-like pain over the right side of her face that radiates from the cheeks and  jaw. She adds that touching the nasal or the perioral region of her face can trigger these episodes. Neurological examination and examination of the head, oral cavity, and temporomandibular joint are within normal limits. MRI of the brain is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has trigeminal neuralgia (TN). TN refers to a chronic pain disorder characterized by severe, brief outbursts of electric-like sharp pain in the trigeminal nerve (V). It most commonly results from compression or inflammation of the trigeminal nerve but can be associated with other disorders such as multiple sclerosis.    

Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug (AED) used as a first-line treatment for partial seizures. Carbamazepine carries additional uses such as first-line treatment of TN and as a mood stabilizer in patients with bipolar disorder.  

Valproic acid and lamotrigine can be used as mood stabilizers in patients with bipolar disorder. Gabapentin, commonly used in partial seizures, is also very effective in treating neuropathic pain (e.g., postherpetic neuralgia, neuropathic pain) and can sometimes be used in the prophylaxis of migraine headaches.



Option Analysis

✅ Carbamazepine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Microvascular decompression:
Incorrect: Microvascular decompression serves as a surgical treatment for trigeminal neuralgia. It is an invasive procedure and should be considered for cases refractory to medical management. 
❌ Radiosurgery :
Incorrect: Radiosurgery is another surgical option for treating trigeminal neuralgia. Surgical treatment is used for cases refractory to medical management. 
❌ Gabapentin:
Incorrect: Gabapentin is a first-line treatment for neuropathy; however, it is not the first-line management of trigeminal neuralgia. 
❌ Levetiracetam :
Incorrect: Levetiracetam is not used in the management of trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of excessive daytime sleepiness. For years, he has felt drowsy during the day despite sleeping 8-10 hours at night. He currently consumes 200-400 mg of caffeine during the day to stay awake. As he is falling asleep, he occasionally sees flashes of light. Sometimes during the day, especially if he is surprised, he feels as if his legs might give out. He has no past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On exam, he is alert, and the remainder of his neurological examination is normal. Oropharyngeal and cardiopulmonary examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following tests should be ordered to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 21-year-old patient presents with excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS), hypnogogic hallucinations, and sudden weakness with strong emotions. The most likely diagnosis is narcolepsy with cataplexy. This sleep disorder can be diagnosed with an overnight polysomnogram and multiple sleep latency tests.      

Overnight video polysomnography (PSG) with or without a multiple sleep latency test (MSLT) can be helpful in determining the etiology for disordered sleep. With narcolepsy, a polysomnogram may show a short mean sleep latency, meaning the patient takes 8 minutes or less, on average, to fall asleep. Short REM sleep latency may also be seen, meaning the patient enters REM sleep within 15 minutes of falling asleep. An MSLT can evaluate for sleep-onset REM periods based on multiple napping opportunities.        

If the PSG is nondiagnostic, cerebrospinal fluid sampling can be diagnostic for narcolepsy. a low hypocretin-1 level, which is a peptide that helps regulate sleep, can be diagnostic. Some patients may have a positive HLA DQB1*0602 genotype.   

Option Analysis

✅ Multiple sleep latency test :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Serum iron level:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency can contribute to restless leg symptoms, but this patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy are concerning for narcolepsy, which can be diagnosed with a multiple sleep latency test. 
❌ Electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: Disrupted sleep, changes in muscle tone, and hallucinations can sometimes occur because of seizures which can be detected with electroencephalography. However, this patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy are concerning for narcolepsy. Narcolepsy can be diagnosed with a multiple sleep latency test. 
❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect: Rarely, in the absence of focal neurological symptoms, would excessive daytime sleepiness, hallucinations, and cataplexy be the result of a lesion detectable by neuroimaging. Rather, this patient’s symptoms are concerning for narcolepsy, which can be diagnosed with a multiple sleep latency test. 
❌ Urine drug screen :
Incorrect: Excessive levels of sedation, falls, and hallucinations could be the result of an ingestion, but this patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy are concerning for narcolepsy, which can be diagnosed with a multiple sleep latency test.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by family for evaluation of abnormal behavior over the past several weeks. The family has observed increasingly odd and argumentative behavior and reports episodes of disorientation in familiar places. Past medical history is non-contributory. The only medication is an oral contraceptive. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/70 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears agitated with pressured speech. When asked to keep the tongue protruding or maintain grip, the patient is unable to sustain the action. No rash is present. A urine drug screen and serum ethanol level are negative. A complete blood count with differential is normal. Which of the following additional historical or examination findings are most consistent with the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Consumption of undercooked meat or raw shellfish

questions.solution:
This young, biologically female adult presents with symptoms suggestive of autoimmune encephalitis, including subacute, progressive confusion and behavioral changes. The absence of infectious features supports an autoimmune etiology. The most likely diagnosis is anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate (anti-NMDA) receptor encephalitis, which is often associated with movement abnormalities such as orofacial or lingual dyskinesias, dystonia, or rigidity.       

A focused history and physical examination can help narrow the differential diagnosis and guide further evaluation and treatment in patients with suspected encephalitis. Common symptoms include new-onset confusion, behavioral or personality changes, headaches, visual disturbances, weakness, numbness, language impairment, incoordination, or seizures. On exam, findings may include altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits, seizures, fever, or rash. When infectious signs are present, evaluation for viral or parasitic causes is warranted.       

In the absence of infection, autoimmune causes should be considered. Rapid-onset symptoms developing over days may suggest acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM). In contrast, anti-NMDA receptor or anti-LGI1 encephalitis evolve over weeks and are often associated with abnormal facial movements, memory impairment, and behavioral disturbances. Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is more common in young adults assigned female at birth, whereas anti-LGI1 encephalitis is more frequently seen in adults older than 50 years of age.  

Option Analysis

✅ Involuntary facial movements:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Unimmunized status:
Incorrect: Lack of vaccination increases the risk for certain preventable causes of encephalitis. This patient’s subacute presentation without signs or symptoms of infection is more consistent with autoimmune encephalitis, which may feature involuntary movements.  
❌ Recent travel to Central America:
Incorrect: Travel to certain regions can increase the risk of specific infections, including cysticercal encephalitis. However, this patient’s subacute presentation without signs or symptoms of infection is more consistent with autoimmune encephalitis, which may feature involuntary movements. 
❌ Consumption of undercooked meat or raw shellfish:
Incorrect: Eating undercooked meat or raw shellfish can increase the risk of certain infections, such as Toxoplasma gondii or Listeria monocytogenes, both of which may cause encephalitis. However, toxoplasmic encephalitis occurs primarily in immunocompromised individuals, and listerial infection typically presents with fever and other systemic signs. This patient’s subacute presentation in the absence of fever or immunosuppression is more consistent with autoimmune encephalitis. 
❌ Family history of similar symptoms:
Incorrect: Genetic disorders such as Huntington disease or Wilson disease can cause neuropsychiatric symptoms, but these typically follow a more gradual course and often present later in life. The subacute onset and rapid progression described here are more characteristic of autoimmune encephalitis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of memory concerns. Over the past year, she has experienced gradually worsening forgetfulness. Important appointments have been forgotten, and completing errands without a list has become difficult. Recently, the patient had trouble finding her car in a parking garage. Family members have noted irritability, especially when difficulty arose with cooking a familiar dish. Past medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux managed with omeprazole. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On exam, the patient is alert, oriented, and interactive. The neurological examination reveals no focal abnormalities, and gait is normal. The patient’s Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score is 23/30, and depression screening suggests no symptoms of depression. Which of the following historical elements should be elicited to evaluate for a reversible cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with symptoms of gradual cognitive decline, including forgetfulness, personality changes, disorganization, and difficulty with visuospatial tasks (e.g. losing her car), along with objective evidence of at least mild impairment on MMSE and no evidence of depression. The diagnostic approach should prioritize reversible causes, such as metabolic conditions like vitamin B12 deficiency and hypothyroidism. Among the answer choices listed, it is important to evaluate dietary habits (e.g., strict vegan or other limited intake of animal products, restricted food intake, fad diets) as a potential contributor to vitamin B12 deficiency.

Gradual cognitive decline refers to the slow and progressive impairment of memory, behavior, personality, organizational skills, decision-making, and visuospatial awareness. It can be caused by a variety of neurological conditions, and some cases may present with a family history of similar symptoms.

The evaluation of an adult presenting with gradual cognitive decline should involve determining, through history and physical examination, whether there is objective evidence of cognitive impairment (e.g. cognitive screens such as the MMSE or MOCA) and if these symptoms are secondary to another condition. Such conditions may include depression (also known as pseudodementia) or treatable, reversible medical conditions like hypothyroidism or vitamin B12 deficiency. Depression screening and laboratory tests, such as a TSH and vitamin B12 level, can aid in the evaluation.

Option Analysis

✅ Dietary habits:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Family history of similar symptoms:
Incorrect: Although some genetic conditions can contribute to gradual cognitive decline, they are typically not easily reversible. Of the answer choices, certain dietary habits may place an individual at risk for nutritional deficiencies (e.g. vitamin B12 deficiency in the setting of a vegan diet), which is a potentially reversible cause of cognitive decline.
❌ Personal history of hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism, rather than hyperthyroidism, is a potentially reversible medical cause of gradual cognitive decline. Of the answer choices, certain dietary habits may place an individual at risk for nutritional deficiencies (e.g. vitamin B12 deficiency in the setting of a vegan diet), which is a potentially reversible cause of cognitive decline.
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: While tobacco use is a significant risk factor for ischemic stroke and vascular dementia, it is not a primary cause of reversible gradual cognitive decline in the same way that vitamin B12 deficiency and hypothyroidism are.
❌ Exercise routine:
Incorrect: While exercise habits are important for overall health, cardiovascular risk, and general cognitive function, a lack of physical activity is not a direct, primary cause of reversible cognitive decline in the same way that conditions like hypothyroidism or vitamin B12 deficiency are.

questions.text: After a high-speed motor vehicle accident, a 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department. The patient was restrained when her vehicle was struck from the passenger side by another vehicle traveling approximately 60 mph (97 km/h). The patient’s primary survey is intact. A secondary survey demonstrates a bleeding laceration and a palpable depression over the temporal bone. The patient reports diminished sensation over her left forehead, nose, mouth, and jaw. The patient’s jaw deviates towards the left when asked to open her mouth. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely damaged based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with a trigeminal nerve injury (CN V)--likely at the trigeminal root or ganglion. The trigeminal nerve carries both sensory and motor innervation to the face and is divided into three major branches: the ophthalmic branch (V1), maxillary branch (V2), and mandibular branch (V3).

The V1 supplies sensation to the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, and the nose. The V2  provides sensation to the area over the maxilla, nasal cavity, sinuses, palate, and mid-face. Lastly, V3  provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication. Thus, patients with injury to the trigeminal root will have absent sensory information over the entire ipsilateral face and weakness or wasting of the muscles of mastication. Weakness of these muscles will result in ipsilateral deviation of the jaw when opened. In addition, V1 provides sensory input regarding the reflex arc for the corneal reflex. Thus damage to this branch or the trigeminal root will result in an absent corneal reflex.  

Option Analysis

❌ CN  I:
Incorrect: The optic nerve, or cranial nerve, provides sensory information regarding sight to the brain.  
✅ CN V:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CN VII:
Incorrect: Cranial nerve VII, or the facial nerve, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.  
❌ CN IX:
Incorrect: Motor function of cranial nerve IX, or the glossopharyngeal nerve, includes innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx during speaking and swallowing.  
❌ CN X:
Incorrect:  The vagus nerve innervates several of the striated muscles of the larynx and pharynx. Damage to this nerve does not result in jaw deviation. Moreover, damage to this nerve would result in autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for routine follow-up. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. On review of systems, she says she has had persistent dizziness for the past month. She does not experience feeling the room spinning. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Cranial nerve examination, including fundoscopy, is within normal limits. There is no nystagmus. She has no tremor, and the rest of the neurologic exam is within normal limits. Which of the following would be consistent with the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent dizziness without an abnormal sensation of motion to suggest vertigo. The differential diagnosis for persistent dizziness is broad but can be narrowed down by assessing the timing of the symptoms and whether they are persistent or episodic. Recent medication changes, especially in the elderly, can lead to persistent dizziness. Cessation of symptoms with discontinuation of the likely causative agent can confirm the diagnosis.       

Medication classes most likely to cause dizziness include diuretics, anti-hypertensives, anti-convulsant, glucose-lowering agents, antibiotics, mucolytics, serotonin and dopamine modulators, cholesterol-lowering agents, anti-malarial, and anti-inflammatory agents.       

In the absence of medication-induced dizziness, a history of head trauma could explain persistent dizziness, especially if it is accompanied by headache, sleep disturbance, mood changes, or change in cognition. Panic disorder should be considered if dizziness is episodic rather than persistent, and accompanied by intense fear, shortness of breath, or chest pain. Alternatively, accompanying tachycardia, presyncope, or pallor may suggest dysautonomia, which can be seen with Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, neuropathies, or migraines.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recent medication change:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Family history of Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: dysautonomia which is a common symptom of Parkinson disease, can cause dizziness; however, it is often episodic, and is the result of intermittent orthostatic hypotension. This patient’s dizziness is persistent, and she has no other symptoms of Parkinson disease. A recent medication change would more likely be the cause of her symptoms. 
❌ Ear fullness and tinnitus:
Incorrect: Ménière’s disease can present with episodic vertigo, hearing loss, ear pressure/fullness, and tinnitus. This patient is experiencing persistent dizziness rather than vertigo and she has no other symptoms of Ménière’s disease. 
❌ Episodes triggered by positional changes:
Incorrect: In patients with Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo head position changes can induce an abnormal sensation of motion or vertigo, but this patient is experiencing persistent dizziness, not vertigo which would be more consistent with a recent medication change. 
❌ History of poorly controlled hypertension:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled hypertension can be associated with a posterior circulation stroke, which can present with persistent vertigo. This patient has normal blood pressure and describes persistent dizziness without a sensation of motion.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion and forgetfulness for the past three weeks. According to a family member, the patient has also been more emotional than usual. Review of systems is negative for recent constitutional symptoms. Past medical history includes hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease, for which the patient takes lisinopril and omeprazole, respectively. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears tearful with intermittent, brief twitching of the left side of the face and arm. A urine drug screen and serum ethanol level are negative. A complete blood count (CBC) with differential is normal. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-LGI1 antibodies
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-NMDA receptor antibodies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of autoimmune encephalitis, including subacute memory loss, emotional lability, and involuntary facial and arm movements consistent with faciobrachial dystonic seizures. The absence of fever or other signs of infection supports a non-infectious etiology. The most likely diagnosis is anti-leucine-rich-glioma-inactivated 1 (LGI1) encephalitis, which can be confirmed by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-LGI1 antibodies.
